  1. Nothing beats an actual razor blade for a close shave, but this is pretty good for the occasional, sort-of-reasonably-close shave. I like that it can get completely wet. And the sideburn feature works very well.
  2. An excellent product. I like and gladly recommend this electric shaver.
  3. I've had other brands of rotary shavers and they all scratched my neck skin since I have a sensitive skin! So I started using razors 7 years ago and I've been almost comfortable with them. However, I could not shave everyday due to the same problem, SENSITIVE SKIN.<br />last month I saw this offer and after some research I realized that foil shavers give better results for sensitives skins. I got this one for less than 50 and since I started using I've had no rash or scar on my neck or face and guess what!...I shave everyday. Totally worth it!

  31. I bought this primarily as a travel shaver, after I converted from electric to blade after 40 years of electric shaving. Largely from the glowing reviews this shaver received here on Amazon. Thing is I get a faster and equally close, if not closer shave using my disposable Panasonic ES3831K electric shaver that is kept in my car's glove box. Now when I travel, I usually travel with the Panasonic which I use morning and evening. If I miss one of those, then I typically shave with a blade, because the blade handles longer beards better than electric shavers. I keep the Braun at home when I want to shave intra-day for touch-up, and even then I often skip the Braun if I'll be driving, and then get the Panasonic out after getting in the car.

  33. Coming from a Remington shaver, I'm not very happy with this one. While the price is reasonable, if your facial hair grows fast, and is thick, I find that this shaver just does not do the job. I often have to go over parts of my face several times to get even a remotely good shave, which causes irritation. It is not because the blade is dull, since I just got this shaver. I would recommend looking at others such as http://www.amazon.com/Remington-R4-5150A-Titanium-Rotatry-Technology/dp/B007GZ72X0/ref=sr_1_4?ie=UTF8&qid=1429274038&sr=8-4&keywords=remington+shaver which is less money, and in my opinion gives a better shave.

  48. only used it once, and it worked fine. I will know more on a later date.
  49. This is an excellent shaver and impervious to water. After you use it just remove the foil shave head and wash it out under warm water. I keep it charged all the time by perching it on its charger, but I think you could go a couple of weeks between charges. I recall one reviewer saying he seldom charged it. This shaver has a sideburn and mustache trimmer that is a nice touch, just be careful when you get close to ears, nose or any body part because it can nick you. It can be elevated and retracted so make sure it is retracted until you're ready to do trimming, and then keep it facing the opposite direction. It will keep your sideburns and mustache nicely sculpted. I like the look, feel, and ease of use of this shaver. It is an outstanding value and an excellent example of the latest shaving technology. You can even use it in the shower, or shave with cream of gel for a real smooth shave, although the lubrication somewhat defeats the cutting ability of the shaver. If you want a 5 o'clock shadow or stubble effect, shaving with cream is the way to go, and it makes for a relaxing, comforting shave. I'm really glad I discovered this shaver because it has saved me tons of $ on straight shaver blades. This shaver is strongly recommended; it delivers a smooth, clean shave and you will not be disappointed. One or two trips to the store to buy standard shaving blades will pay for this electric shaver. You can use it to shave body hair with decent results, but again, watch out for nicks with the retractable sideburn trimmer. This shaver is primarily designed for facial shaving.
  50. This product is effective.
  51. it is no match for a blade.takes a long time to get a close shave.even so ,it is really not close.i would not recommend it...i have yet to find an electric shaver that cando what it puports to do...
  52. I've used electric shavers for about 40 years, which included Remington, Norelco, Panasonic, and Braun models. My previous unit was also a Braun Series 3-340 shaver which held up well and was still working when I bought this current edition. The reason I replaced the older unit was that I had dropped the shaver a few times and the sideburn trimmer had fallen apart as a result. After 5 years of use, the shaver still shaved well and its' battery was still going strong. This current model shaves my usual 3-day growth extremely well and is quieter than the previous unit. I love how the blades/head hug the contours around my chin and jaw. It is also easier to clean than my previous shaver, easier to handle, and comes with a head protector and a charging stand. I've had this shaver for 3 weeks and so far have got around 8 shaves off the first charge which is impressive. Time will tell how the unit holds up and how long the battery lasts but I am well pleased so far and would definitely buy one again.
  53. very good, I care much
  54. Replacing my old Braun after many years of service. The only brand I would ever buy. The new one shaves perfectly and needs recharging only every few weeks.
  55. I bought this to replace a ten year old electric that I used for a quick touch up between blade shaves. I've used this one by itself for the last few weeks and I find that it does a reasonably good job. The initial charge experience was a bit strange,because the green charge light does NOT stay lit throughout the charging process. I thought that there was a problem, but I contacted Braun Tech services and found out this was normal. The initial charge took about seven or eight hours and I now charge it for about an hour once a week when the red low battery light turns on.<br /><br />The razor itself shaves relatively close on face, cheek, and chin areas. I find that I need to spend a lot of time with the trimmer on the neck and upper lip area. I generally daily shave after my morning shower. I do NOT use this in the shower though I think you can. It cleans easily under running water and there is a small brush that helps. It appears to be well sealed enough to use in the shower, but that's just not my routine. It's not as close as a blade shave, but it does fine for me. It has improved after a few weeks as my face has adapted to regular use of an electric again.<br />There was a little redness and irritation on my neck for the first few days.<br /><br />This is a reasonably priced alternative to the electrics with the fancy cleaning systems that can cost $200-$400. I just can't see spending that amount of money. I also think that it's crazy to spend $3 or $4 a week for disposable razors or blades. This is a much more environmentally friendly and economical alternative in my opinion. I look forward to years of regular use. though I may hang on to my blade razor to use once a week or so for a really close shave. It should be noted that the manufacturer recommends changing the screen and cutter assembly about every eighteen months. These seem to be fairly available on Amazon at a cost in the mid $20 range.
  56. Great close shave, long lasting battery, easy cleaning.<br />First time user of non-Phillips shaver...happy I made the switch! Highly recommended.

I found I had to go over my face a few more passes than the triple header to get all the whiskers and sometimes I will feel a long hair on my face that the Braun missed a few times for it to get that long. Also when shaving without a shirt I feel the cut whiskers bouncing off my chest and I can scrape up a small pile of cut whiskers on the counter by the bathroom sink. The triple header collects the cut whiskers better. I gave it 3 stars because it is not a bad shaver but I will be returning to a Triple header.

  85. I originally purchased the highly rated Panasonic Vortex ES8249. The Panasonic has 4 blades and is extremely well built. It also comes with an automatic cleaning station. Why did I end up returning it and keeping the Braun instead? The Panasonic does provide a very close shave however I found that I have to go over certain areas several times to accomplish a close shave. The Braun has only 3 blades however I was able to get a closer and faster shave with the Braun with just 1-2 passes. I have been able to get a razor close shave with the Braun within 3 minutes. I found the shave to actually be more precise and closer than the Panasonic. The Panasonic would take me over 5 minutes. The build quality of the Braun is excellent. It is built like a tank and very comfortable to hold. It has a rubber liner that makes holding it very secure and comfortable. It is actually much quieter than the Panasonic. The Panasonic has a very loud high pitched sound....similar to a hair trim clipper that barbers use. The one complaint that I do have is that Braun should have included a protective cover for the blades. It does come with a protective travel case however a guard is a must to protect the most delicate part of the shaver which is the foils. The price, performance, build quality and low cost of maintenance makes this an excellent value. The replacement blade/foil runs around $20 compared to $50 for the Panasonic.

  138. After reviewing several electric shavers, I bought this one as a Christmas gift. My guy has very sensitive skin, so I was worried about the shaver irritating his skin. Also, he's not someone who is going to read through manuals and follow specific cleaning directions. I wanted a shaver that'd be easy to clean and delicate on skin. At first, I considered a Panasonic shaver due to the simple rinse-under-water cleaning method. But for the Panasonic, several reviews mentioned the need to replace foils and blades every 6 months. In addition to this, they were also displeased by the expense of such foils and blades.<br /><br />The Braun Series 3-340s checked all the boxes and exceeded my expectations. The closeness of shave is as good as a five blade Gillette razor, with no irritation. I really can't tell the difference in the shave between the shaver or the razor. In terms of the battery, he charged it for half the day on Dec. 26th, and he's used it nearly every day since (today being 1/10) and the battery is still working strong from the initial charge. The shaver is very easy to clean by shaking it under running water. Also, the manual states to replace the foils every 18 months, plus they are half the price of the Panasonic foils.<br /><br />I didn't expected him to use it so often, let alone call it his favorite gift. All around, we are both extremely pleased with this product.

  165. Over 40 odd years of shaving I've tried several electric shavers and none of them lived up to the hype or claims. It's been years since I've used an electric.<br /><br />But, the Braun was on sale at Amazon and I was really &#34;itching&#34; to try a newer generation electric shaver. So I ordered it.<br /><br />In my opinion this electric shaver does everything the manufacturer claims. It really works well and I'm very pleased that I bought it. It's easy to use, provides a very close shave and it's easy to clean. I really can't find a downside.<br /><br />It really works well with just a day or two of beard stubble. If I let it go any longer it seems to have some trouble with the longer whiskers. But, Braun also tells you that's the case, so fair enough. My job doesn't require that I be clean-shaven every day so I don't. But this electric really makes shaving, which I really don't like doing, much easier and convenient.<br /><br />It's a quality product, it feels substantial in the hand, comes apart easily for cleaning and will provide numerous shaves between charges. The attached trimmer works well, too, though I haven't used it a lot. I also haven't had the need to use the shaver in &#34;wet&#34; mode, such as in the shower. Braun recommends shaving before washing your face and that seems to be what works best.<br /><br />If you're looking for a good electric shaver that really works well and is reasonably priced, you'll have a hard time finding a better one.

I've bought several over the years and most of them cost multiple times what this model is being sold for.<br /><br />This razor performs as advertised, and the build quality is better than I had expected at this price. My facial hair grows quickly. I keep this razor in my car for times when I am away from home or on the road for extended periods of time and unable to conveniently use a straight razor and oil to get a proper shave. I am more than satisfied with the quality and price. It came with a handy stand, and a plastic guard that protects the blade and most importantly, prevents the razor from accidentally turning on as it rolls around in your bag. When this one wears out, I'll likely buy another of the same model. Does it perform like a $300 razor? Probably not, but with the price and relative quality of this model, I sometimes wonder why I ever bought all of those expensive razors.

  228. Had an earlier series BRAUN and loved it too...but when it came time for another cutter and foil change, this Series 3-340s was priced not much higher than replacement parts, so I bought it...Man am I happy! This one works even better than my old unit when it was new...Better battery life, and closer shave...You know from the picture I honestly thought the &#34;head&#34; (cutter and foil&#34; were the same basic configuration as my old unit, But I noticed that while the foil is pretty much similar, the cutting head is TOTALLY different...anyway the net effect is a closer, quicker shave.<br />I also like the redesigned side burn trimmer. The trimmer slides up like the old one, BUT the actual cutting surface is at a 90 degree angle away from the shaver, and while it might &#34;sound&#34; strange&#34; - it WORKs better...better visibility of the trimmer and &#34;target&#34; surface, and less skin irritation.<br />I also considered the 3-360/80, but I have never had trouble trimming below my nose, and THIS unit works fine for that without the need for the extra &#34;lever&#34; that the more expensive units have.

  280. I have been using Remington shavers for years, but since they started coming from China, the build quality has been steadily declining. They recently redesigned the screen and cutter to make it cheaper to produce and rendered it virtually useless. I decided to jump ship and paid quite a bit more for a Braun, thinking they might still be made in Europe. WRONG! They're made in China like most everything else these days.<br /><br /> I have been using the Braun Series 3 model 340s for the better part of a year now and here's what I found. It seems to take half again as long to complete a shave as the older Remingtons and it's nearly impossible to remove all the hair from the neck area just below the chin. Granted, that's not easy to do, but the Braun has a special screen and cutter in between the main screens that's supposed to get the longer hairs. It doesn't cut them and tends to pull them instead. My four-o'clock shadow appears a little after noon time. Now, my beard is neither heavy nor dark in color, sad to say that it's mostly gray these days. The battery doesn't stay charged as long as previous shavers I've had, probably due to the additional time it takes to shave with this one. We're talking less than a week, while I've had others last 10-11 days.<br /><br /> Braun has a 60-day money back guarantee, but be advised that one of the requirements is that you need to send it back in the original packaging. Stupid me, I threw it out before I read the paperwork. This shaver is going to need the screen kit replaced in a couple of months, but I don't think I'll bother, I'll just try another brand. Not sure what, though...

  283. I'm writing this to all the people who are unhappy with the closeness of this shaver. I usually don't write reviews, but I felt I had to write this particular product. I purchased the Braun 3Series 340S-4 Wet & Dry Shaver in April of 2013. In the past I had always been a rotary Norelco man. I wouldn't even look at a screen shaver. I was under the misconception that rotarys give a close shave. Was I mistaken. This shaver gives the closest and I mean closets shave I have EVER had. It's funny, when I first bought it I felt that i got a comparable shave as my old rotary which consistently left stubble in the hollow areas of my neck which was something I became accustomed to. So after a month of use I figured not much difference, but I might as well keep using it since I paid good money for it and it did give me a comparable shave. Well, I'm glad I did. After 2 months of stubble, all of a sudden NO MORE STUBBLE ! I can only attribute it to my skin adapting to the shaver. Getting to the bottom line, If you don't get immediate results don't throw in the towel consider waiting an extra month or so to allow your skin to adapt to this shaver. Ypu'll be glad you did because you will be rewarded with a close shave. All I can say is good bye Norelco.

  311. Like many other Norelco owners, I was forced to return to the Braun camp on account of Norelco having discontinued manufacture of replacement parts for their best electric razor(s). :-( I thought this Braun unit would be an adequate substitute.<br /><br />For three months I used this Braun model, and every time I cursed it and deeply regretted my purchase of it. It chafed me, it cut me (regularly), and I could not get a close enough shave with it no matter how hard I tried. In four decades of shaving I could not remember any electric razor causing me so much grief. Now I am going to explain away the Achilles' heel of this razor AND give you the solution to the problem!!<br /><br />WHY was the problem occurring? Because I wasn't following instructions, obviously—LOL. Yes, I was using it in the shower—which you are NOT supposed to do and I do NOT recommend you do.<br /><br />However, the precautions never say anything remotely close to &#34;Never use this razor on a wet face!&#34;—so let us proceed under the assumption that you are merely using the razor on a (your) wet face.<br /><br />This model comes with a small tube of oil—don't lose it! In the manual, Braun advises that &#34;if you regularly clean the shaver under water, then once a week apply a drop of light machine oil onto the long hair trimmer…and shaver Foil & Cutter cassette.&#34;<br /><br />The instruction SHOULD go something like this: &#34;If you like to completely wet your face before shaving, no problem, you will LOVE the awesomely close shave you'll receive every time. ALL you have to remember is this: Every Single Time You Shave, you MUST MUST MUST remember to apply a drop of light machine oil (from the tube we so smartly have included with this model) onto a fingertip, and then carefully rub said oil into every single square millimeter of the long hair trimmer AND all the outward-facing metal parts of the shaver Foil & Cutter cassette.&#34;<br /><br />tl;dr: keep the Foil & Cutter cassette oiled (oil it after every wet shave!), and you will love this razor

  339. I have used Panasonic Wet/Dry shavers in the past and this one works just as well for about half the price of what I paid before for my last Panasonic. I've been using the Braun for about 3 weeks now. The main difference is the motor is a little slower than what I'm used to but the shave quality is fine. I still do minor clean up with a regular razor but I had to do that with previous wet/dry brands as well. Very sturdy - would recommend.

  341. I use the Braun 340 as a wet-shaver, with a small amount of shave gel, and the results are excellent.<br />The 340 delivers a close and comfortable shave, in fact, the most comfortable shave I've ever had.<br />Over the years, I've used many different electric shavers -- Norelco, Panasonic and Remington -- and this one tops them all.<br />The shaver has a nice weight and feel and maintenance is a snap, just rinse it after shaving.<br />I cannot tell you how it performs dry because I only use it wet.<br />If you're a fan of wet electric shaving, you'll want to consider the Braun 340.<br />This one is a winner.

  345. OK, I'll get right to the point: I was looking for a multi-groom trimmer, because I'm a guy and I like to keep everything trimmed &#34;down under&#34;. The trimmers I have had in the past did not do the job adequately. This trimmer works perfectly: with the adjustable blade guards on, you can remove as much of the hair as you want, and there is absolutely no pain or pulling or pinching in the very sensitive areas on a man (I'm sure the men reading this, know of what I speak). I have not used the trimmer for grooming my hair, nor do I have any facial hair, so I can't comment on those aspects. However, for body hair trimming, this trimmer works perfectly. And the price is amazing!
  346. Decent shave, but no where near a razor. The skin has to be tight and without curves or it doesnt cut close to the skin. I really love this shaver and am glad I didn't spend the money for a 380S-4 which the only difference is a travel case and a button to depress the foil on one end (supposedly to get a closer shave under the nose, etc.) It would have cost $30 more for a feature I don't really need.   400. The Very best Shaver I have ever had.
  401. I am a 45 year old guy who has never been able to shave every day. I usually shaved once a week with the typical 5 blade razor and shaving cream. If I tried to shave every day, my face would break out and I could not stand the pain of shaving it every day. I just started a new job where a clean shaven face is an unspoken rule. I knew the old stand by manual razor was not going to work. I started looking for an electric razor to use. I spent time researching on line to see what I wanted to get. I knew I wanted a braun but was not sure which one. I chose the 340-S because of the lower price and the fact that it is a wet dry shaver. I have had it a week now and have shaved every day but yesterday. The first couple of days there was some burning but really nothing that bad. This morning was basically pain free. As for the shave, it is pretty good. My hair grows in multiple directions and almost in circles in some places on my face so it has been tough to get them all. I also have very coarse, tough whiskers. I think with more time, I will figure out what I need to do to get all of them shaved and close. The places the braun does get all the whiskers, the shave is comparable to a manual razor and shaving cream. When I am done my face is soft and ready for the day. What more could I ask for?
  402. Great product, very satisfied, especially for the price.
  403. It is very well shave. Good
  404. Gave it to my son for Christmas and so I'm not sure how he likes it so far ?
  405. I only shave wet, at the end of my shower. I use shaving oil, but no creams. I have a tough, fast growing beard that has a grain that goes many directions. I also shave those dozen hairs on the top of my bald head once a week.<br /><br />For years I used a Panasonic 8103 shaver and liked it. I maintained it properly, but it suddenly started to scrape and nick my face. It wasn't right after changing anything either. I never figured out why it started ripping up my face, but it didn't seem to have anything wrong with it either. It may have had to do with an old guy who lost weight and the skin is looser and thinner than in years gone by.<br /><br />I then tried a Philips Norelco 1250x. It was smoother and the contour forming was better, but not that significant. I thought that the rotary action would mean it would work equally in all directions. Not really. It still only works best against the grain of the whiskers - like all shavers. It was the \\"best\\" at cutting of longer hairs, but the worst at making a clean line when doing so. I liked it better than the Panasonic, but after a month it quit working after a recharge. It took me a few days to get to the pain of the warranty process and when I tried it, it was working. It turns out that it is over charging and shutting itself off as a safety issue. When the charge drops down to spec, it works again. That isn't workable, except as a backup shaver.<br /><br />I never had a Braun shaver before and figured it was time to try. This is the best shaver I've ever had. It's the smoothest with the fewest nicks (almost never). It's the closest, even though the others weren't much worse. It isn't particularly good at long hairs, but that makes it safer for the edges. It has the best trimmer, but that isn't saying much as most shavers have completely useless trimmers. This one is actually useful. I thought the ergonomics would be worse on this shaver, but it isn't an issue. It's easy to hold and use in all necessary positions.<br/><br />When I first got it, the charge would last about a week and half. It slowly dropped to a week. It turns out that the orange light for low battery gives a very generous warning time - a little too long. So the battery memory was shortening. I started letting the shaver run all the way down when the orange light came on. The battery memory has returned back to normal and I'm back to 1.5 weeks between charges.<br /><br />I've not tried any of these for dry shaving, so this is a wet-only review. Braun recommends shaving before cleaning, but I've always had the best results shaving at the end of my shower. If you shave wet, I can highly recommend this Braun 340S as the best option. Of course, your beard may be different, but it is certainly and easily the best I've ever used.<br /><br />7 Months of use.

It was for this reason that I decided to return the shave and instead opted for a replacement in this shave http://amzn.to/1L4UcN2 which does exactly what is promised and gives you a close shave no matter what the region. I've had this replacement for around 3 months now and can honestly say I havent looked back!!

  410. easy to learn how to use, comfortable, recharge very quickly
  411. [[VIDEOID:f8e2938c12335db16461032e942b00ca]]I bought this shaver to replace my Panasonic ES8103 shaver. This is heavier at 7.2 oz as compared to the 5.9 oz of the Panasonic ES8103. It seems like the braun shaver is heavier than it actually is. The cut this provides is a pretty good shave, though it isn't the best I've ever used. However, for the money paid, it does the job. The shaver has a green light to show that there is a charge above 20% and a red light that flashes when the battery is low. Compared to other shaver, I tend to miss the LED percentages that give a more accurate idea of the charge status. However, most people this wouldn't be an issue since you have it by the sink where you could plug it in with easy. My biggest con of this shaver is that even with cleaning the hair out after ever 2 uses, the little hair trimmings seem to pour out when I use the razor. I'll pick the razer off my desk and hair trimmings will fall out of it and it's frankly quite annoying. It's enough of a problem that I turn this new shaver into the backup of my old Panasonic shaver. I give this a 4 star since 3 stars would probably be unfair as some of my complaints probably won't be an issue with some people. Pro - good shaver - battery life seems decently good Con - hair trimmings get everywhere - a little heavier than some other razors *If I've helped, let me know by hitting \\"helpful\\"*

  452. PROS<br />Works great! Gives a nice, clean shave. The trimmer works as it should. Battery lasts pretty long on a single charge. It looks good and feels right in my hand. Auto voltage of 100v to 240v makes it suitable for travel. Can be used dry or with shaving foam or gel.<br /><br />CONS<br />The triple cutting system (a trimmer in between 2 foil shavers) takes getting used to. Although it shaves quite nicely, it feels unusual on my face. I have to shave at an angle when I prefer to use just the foil shaver and not the trimmer in the middle. Also, because of the triple blade design, the shaver head is pretty bulky.

I have not been disappointed.<br /><br />Pros:<br />* Extremely close shave, as close as a new disposable razor without the risk of nicks.<br />* Wet or dry. Works great with a tiny bead of Edge shaving gel which I put on the foil before using.<br />* You can press as hard as you like and it will never cut you.<br />* Very well designed. Feels sturdy in the hand. The charging base is compact and light, yet feels stable.<br />* Easy to clean the head, easy to replace the head when necessary.<br />* Cleverly designed foil head. The outer foils shave the stubble while the center part of the head cuts the longer hairs.<br />* Convenient trimmer on the side for any remaining stragglers and tidying up sideburns.<br />* Comes with a protective cap which is convenient for travel.<br />* The battery life is fantastic.<br />* High speed shaving elements for a quicker shave.<br /><br />Cons:<br />* It's a little heavy, but that contributes to the solid feel.<br /><br />I strongly preferred this shaver to the Panasonic rotary shaver I tried.

This new shaver now has a trimmer blade in between the two foils. Before, if you beard is long you have to use the side trimmer to cut it short and then use the foil to shave it clean. Now I use the the foil/trimmer on top to do one shave and be done with it. On top of that the battery last a very long time on a single charge.

  515. I stand by the notion that the best shave you'll ever get is a straight, manual razor. However, since I hate having to cut my face to hell everyday and deal with buying expensive replacements every so often, I figure I'd give an electric razor a chance. It took me a while to determine which was better, a foil or a rotary, and I ended up going with foil cause it cuts closer and is irritation free (for me at least). I bought this foil razor after reading a lot of reviews, because for the cheap price, it had pretty high ratings. It looks sturdy, feels sturdy, and is definitely not loud. The trimmer is pretty nice too, and I definitely advise using that first on your hair if you more than stubble growth, otherwise you're in for a painful ride. I've used this both dry, wet, with foam, in the shower, and it's wonderful, but I will say the absolute best shave I got was with foam. After shaving with this thing and shaving gel, it was exactly like a shaved with a straight razor, except with half the time and discomfort. Shaving dry is nice, but you can just see a bit of shadow on your face, but it all depends on the kind of facial hair growth you have. Battery life is....as expected? I shave every single day in the morning for about 4-5 minutes with this thing, and i'll have to recharge it by the end of the week, assuming I started on Sunday. For me that's no issue, and the charging takes a mere 1 hour, so it's barely an inconvenience.<br /><br />OVERALL: Highly recommend, if you have doubts, no worries, this thing is worth the money. Though be sure to keep tabs on this one, cause the price fluctuates between 59.99 to 49.99 and sometimes they give coupons for it too. Enjoy the product!
  516. This is the best deal for any shaver. I have owned the expensive ones $200 plus and this is exactly the same item, but at a quarter of the price. Buy this one over the expensive models and you will not be disapointed.

  537. Good close shave and great battery life. Unfortunately, the foil is very thin when compared to higher end shavers and damages very easily. Plan to handle it very gently, as any small bump or bounce can ruin the foil and render the shaver unusable. Replacement heads are available, and at the time of this review cost about $25. In the long run, you may end up paying the price of a higher end shaver to keep this one running.

  552. I've purchase 2 Braun 340 wet/dry shavers. Good shave considering my beard is very thick. However, both of the shavers have failed after about 12-18 months. The on/off switch on both of them broke. Luckily I found the receipt from the 2nd one. Braun claims it's under warranty. So I'm sending it back 08/27/2012 for repair. I purchased the second on 04/16/2011. My 9 year old electric Norelco is still working, so it's my current shaver. It too is a wet/dry shaver. However, it is not as close as the Braun. So Braun will have one chance to fix the problem or I'll start shopping for a new shaver. Quality of both Braun shavers are similar however, the craftsmanship and longevity is less then desired.<br /><br />Update to review as of 09/13/2012. August 27, 2012, I mailed back both Braun Shavers with a note to Braun that they both had the same problem and purchase reciept to the most recent purchase. The On/Off switch wouldnt function. I even offered to pay for the repair of the older 2nd shaver. Well today, FedEx delivered two (2) brand new Braun 340-s Wet/Dry shavers. No charge for either. Braun replaced both of them. Thanks Braun for the replacement shavers and let's hope that they last a long time.
  553. this is one of the nicest electric razors I have ever owned, and I have had a few. It will shave almost as close as a blade. It rinses nicely, is easy to hold, and is pleasant to use.
  554. I liked this for the first couple weeks I had it, but I couldn't get a consistent close shave (especially on my neck), so I've switched back to a razor. I still use it occasionally and enjoy the fact that it is waterproof.
  555. I bought the Braun 340S several weeks ago to replace my old Japanese-made Panasonic ES8066. I bought that between six and nine years ago--not sure exactly. The trimmer on it has gone bad and has pinched my skin several times causing large painful bumps when shaving my neck. Otherwise it still works pretty well though the battery-life is about half what it was when new. I have definitely gotten my money's worth.<br /><br />I don't like the designs of the current Panasonics and they are no longer made in Japan. So, I considered buying either this Braun or a Philips AT830 as a replacement. The Philips costs about $15 more than what I was able to buy the Braun for in local stores (not Amazon). I have never owned a Philips shaver. I like their quietness but doubt one would shave as close as a foil shaver. And, the head design would make it more difficult to shave precisely around my goatee.<br /><br />I had a Braun shaver that was heavily marketed about ten years ago. It was compact for travel and I initially liked the design. But, it was not a good shaver. It had a single cutter and was like trying to mow your entire lawn with a string trimmer. There was just not enough cutting area. The battery was wimpy. It could be used while plugged in, so that helped negate the battery problem. It only lasted a little over a year. In spite of this, I decided to go with the Braun 340S given their 60-day trial period. I have only used the shaver dry. If I wanted to shave with the muss and fuss of gel or foam, I would just use a blade. Mostly I use soap and water to do an extra good cleaning of the shaver.<br /><br />Compared to my workhorse Panasonic, the Braun's motor runs slower. This gives the impression of being weaker. However after a week of shaving one side of my face with the Braun and the other with the old Panasonic with a new foil my impression is the Braun may shave slightly closer. Shaving time seems about the same. I think the Braun gets neck hairs better. But, you have to work at them. I used to use the Panasonic's trimmer for my neck before it quit working properly.<br /><br />Replacing the Braun foil-cutter assembly is recommended every 18 months. Philips recommends 12 months. Panasonic recommends 12 months for the foil and 24 months for the cutter. These costs definitely add to your total shaving costs, especially if you don't search for a good deal.<br /><br />I like the design of the Braun including the grip-ability of the rubber on the sides and the ridges on the front and back. The curve of the body helps keep the head positioned properly against your skin. The trimmer is straightforward and does a good job. After several charges, I get up to 12 days of shaving on a charge. Some reviews criticize the lack of a travel case for this model. But the plastic head-cap offers good protection including blocking accidental pressing of the On Button. If you don't have a case, you could just stuff it in one of your clean socks during travel. It fits well in the velvet case I still have from my old Panasonic so, for me, there is no issue.<br /><br />In summary, I rate the Braun 340S as 4-stars. It is as good as, but not superior to, anything I have used. Reviews lead me to believe other shavers may be superior, e.g., the Braun Series 7. But, for 2.5x the price of this shaver I doubt they are worth it. A blade shaves closer but for me not enough so to be worth the fuss of lathering up other than for special occasions.
  556. Just got it one day ago. The shave is perfect. I can shave very clean. But there is a sort of weird smell coming out from blades when I shave. Sort of metallic smell. I don't smell anything from Philips shaver that I bought last time. Only Braun has it! Other than the weird smell, everything is fine so far.

I couldn't be happier with my decision to buy an electric razor and I am even happier that this one was so inexpensive and works so well. I would recommend this razor to ANYONE!

  577. I was hesitant to purchase the Braun Series 3 as I've always been a blade man but when a pack of my favorite blades hit $30 at the drugstore I decide to give it a try. This razor definitely takes a few days to get used to but I am glad I stuck with it. At first, the friction caused some irritation and it didn't seem to give me a very close shave particularly on the neck. I got around this by using it in the shower with some shave cream which greatly improved the experience. The irritation stopped occurring after a couple weeks and now I mainly use it dry with no problem at all. It gives me the freedom to shave on the go, is fairly quiet and easy to clean. Plus I am getting 4 - 5 shaves on a charge which is better than expected. The shave is not quite as close a blade but really not much of a difference. Overall happy with this purchase.
  578. Just a little preface - I am 31 years old and have I shaved with a Gillette Mach 3 razor since I was about 16. I do not have a cousin IT style beard, I grow with regular facial hair thickness/coverage on my chin and upper lip but I have spotty hair growth on my cheek and jaw line area. Typically, I would shave every other day with my manual razor but I have grown tired of nicks, cuts and the occasional razor burn leading me to try an electric razor.<br /><br />Now on to the Braun 3-340s, I have really enjoyed shaving with the razor. I was apprehensive at first not knowing what to expect or how to really shave with the electric razor. I read over the manual while I let the charger fully charge for 4 hours. The razor exceeded my expectations, it provides a nick free close shave with minimal effort. I have shaved with the electric razor dry each time without any shaving cream and the shave is almost as close has my manual razor but the elimination of shaving cream, cuts, nicks, red spots etc is more than worth having not as close as a shave. I don’t mean by not as close that I have stubble or I am unhappy but you do not get the same level of smoothness as you do with a manual razor because the electric razor is cutting just your facial hair and not also removing a tiny amount of skin with each shave.<br /><br />I have shaved three days in a row for about 5-7 minutes each time and the battery is still strong. Your battery life will be reflective to the thickness of your beard and how often you shave. The razor is easy to clean, I pop the head off, knock it against the sink a few times, brush the body (not the head) and I am good to go. I will every three days clean the razor with a little hand soap to keep it nice and clean.<br /><br />So far I am extremely happy with the razor and I doubt I will go back to a manual razor again. Getting this shaver for $50 was well worth the money and I would recommend it to anyone.<br /><br />Thanks for reading and I hope you enjoy the razor!the razor!
  579. The razor works fine but does not work in the series 3 cleaning station.
  580. I use both rotary and foil shavers , and this Braun actually performs pretty well . All electric shavers require making a few passes to get a clean shave, but ultimately you do get comparable results to a blade. The 340s does a great job and the price can't be beat .

  608. The last time I used an electric shaver I was 15, about 14 years ago, and I HATED it. It cut me, pinched me and pulled my facial hair. I was apprehensive to buy another one. I have very sensitive skin, especially on my neck, and it doesn't irritate my skin at all, even when shaving dry. It's a great and comfortable shave.   617. I've never been able to use an electric razor because every time I did my face always ended up very dry and/or torn up. I'm not sure if it's just my skin or the razors I've chosen, but since I have been using the Braun 3Series 340S-4 Wet & Dry Shaver I have not had ANY of these problems. It's super easy to clean, it charges quickly, and it fits well in my hand while shaving. Oh, and the price is great.<br /><br />Pros:<br />1. This shaver is excellent - it provides the best shave I have ever had from an electric shaver, and it comes about 90% as close as the shave I have been able to achieve with disposable razors.<br />2. The shaver works dry, wet (with just water), and wet (with shaving cream). It can also be used in the shower without any risk of damage. I found that it cuts best with shaving cream after wetting your face with warm water, but I have dry shaved with it as well and it does quite well.<br />3. It is VERY easy to clean. The directions recommend adding a drop of oil to it once a week if you clean it under water, but that is a small inconvenience for the ease of cleaning achieved by running it under water while running. It takes somewhere between 15 - 30 seconds to thoroughly clean the head. Ease of cleaning was one of the major reasons I had not recently tried an electric shaver, but this makes it easy.<br /><br />Cons:<br />None that I can think of now.

  632. yes, my face is very soft and honestly this shaves as close as the 4-5 blade razors. I bought new blades for 19$ for 4 and thought wow, that's ridiculous. So I did a little research and bought this and am very glad I did. Shaves extremely close, is quiet, the battery lasts for at least one week (using daily) and it has a great little trimmer for sideburns or neck hair. If you want an electric razor, spend no more, look no more. this is it. It also is waterproof and specifically states you can use with shaving gel/foam and or soap. I don't but you can, probably ladies would be interested in that. Its much better than the braun I had 30 years ago, but not much has changed. I guess when its not broken, braun isn't going to fix it. That is impressive.<br /><br />UPDATE 9/2014: OK, I have been using this for several months now, and thought I would update. First off, the good:<br />1- Shaves good --IF CLEAN.<br />2- Great battery life, (1 week plus)<br />3- light weight<br />4- nice charger stand<br />5- easy to disassemble and clean<br />6 trimmer works great<br /><br />THE BAD:<br /><br />If this is not cleaned (rinsed out with blade off), every 2 days or so, you will notice the quality of the shave declines rapidly. It will get to the point it almost does nothing. So its imperative you keep this cleaned out. The other issue I have is that the trimmer is very awkward and kind of ungainly. Its good for trimming side burns, but its almost worthless for trimming around ears or neck because of the size and angles that the trimmer is mounted.<br /><br />All in all for under 60$ I am very impressed and very happy. Initially I was going to remove a star, but as I think about it, my big issue is that I need to clean it? I mean that is a given, and how can I deduct for that. I point it out so that you are aware of it and you keep yours cleaned vs thinking its not working.<br /><br />I hope this is helpful.

  656. It`s gift for dad,pretty good.
  657. Very good item and seller, Thank you so much<br />SO nice
  658. It's pretty unreasonable to expect any electric razor to give a close shave in a pass or two; manufacturers can't possibly know how fast a &#34;pass&#34; will be, or at what angle whiskers are growing. One always has to do many passes over cheek or neck from different angles to get a very smooth result. That's life.<br /><br />I've been a Panasonic user for 11 years. Have always gotten a very close shave. First one lasted 3 years. Last one has lasted 8 years...and without changing any foils or blades! (And my beard is no softer than anyone's.) So Panasonic has been good value for me.<br /><br />However, Panasonic has gotten incredibly expensive, and they all have &#34;arc&#34; shapes which is opposite what a face needs...and they went down the &#34;ultra high rpms&#34; road, which I believe is wasted wear and tear...not to mention loud. 13,000 new whiskers can't possibly find themselves into the same foil hole in a second's time. At most a dozen, and likely far less. So a couple hundred rpm ought to be more than enough.<br /><br />That was part of my theory when I went looking for alternatives to the Panasonic price tag. I've tried rotary models (Norelco) which work quietly but don't give nearly as close a shave (although they do the job enough to go to work and such). And I've tried a Remington foil model, but found that Remington gets their money not up front but on foil replacements--the foil warps and then tears/breaks after 3 months. Not good.<br /><br />So this time I tried Braun. Didn't need any fancy clean-and-lube features (skin has a little oil on it anyway). This Braun 340s is very nice. Much quieter than the Panasonic, slower speed, low-frequency rumble...but the shave is just as good. Could even be superior, although I'm comparing a new Braun to an 8-year-old Panasonic. Still, it takes me no longer to shave than it ever did. Braun says their foils have hole openings that aren't uniformly round, and that probably helps the result.<br /><br />An admittedly bizarre-sounding side benefit which no one ever mentions is that the low rumble vibration of the Braun is low enough frequency that your face can feel it. It's a bit like a face muscle massage (compared to the Panasonic). Sounds ridiculous? Yeah, well, the face has a lotta muscles, believe it or not; keeping them &#34;fit&#34; and flexible has been shown to keep a face from sagging and making a guy look like a 100-year-old basset hound before he's all that old. If I care enough to want to shave, I care enough to not have jowls before my time. The Braun feels good on the muscles. (I don't know, maybe I need it because I grimace too much.) For what it's worth....<br /><br />This Braun shaver has a solid, durable feel to it. Has a small charging stand that's all you need. Seems to charge quickly. The side-burns/moustache trimmer is superior to the one on my Panasonic. It's just as easy to dump whiskers out of the Braun. And (sorry to be so graphic, but) the whisker dust is a lot less fine, courtesy once again of the lower frequency. You can see the diff very easily. And there's a lot more of it when it's dumped out--which means my Panasonic was chopping whiskers into a dust so fine it was losing that dust out the foil holes...onto the bathroom counter, my shirt, etc. I never knew it until now.<br /><br />Bottom line, I like the Braun a lot.<br /><br />Can't speak about how long the battery, foils or blade will last, as I've only had it about a month. Feels durable. Since you can also get a better deal with a Braun, I expect this 340s to give me equal (maybe superior) value to the Panasonic models I've used before.<br /><br />If my Panasonic's battery was still lasting through a full shave every day (which it wasn't), I wouldn't have shopped for a Braun. But if, like me, it's time for you to consider a new razor, I'd recommend this Braun 340s. Good machine.
  659. You will love this razor. Had the first model for 6 years, now enjoying this one as much. Clean the razor head often it will pay off with a close comfortable shave.
  660. Works Real good, gave me a great shave.
  661. Simply put - best shaver I ever owned. Glad I just pulled the trigger and bought it. You won't find a better shaver for $50.

Since I am into the 'scruffy' look when I shave every few days up to a week it has become difficult with manual blades clogging up and shaving difficult. Just received the new Braun 3 series .... WHY DIDN&#34;T I BUY THIS BEFORE NOW!!! Works great! Doesn't wreck my skin... may give up scruffy for clean shaven!

Amazon was awesome enough to refund it since it was within 30 days. Went with the 320S-4 after that since I do mostly dry shaving anyway.
  666. Very good product. Does well what is made for.
  667. If you expect to buy an electric razor and beat the closeness of a manual razor, your expectations might be too high, but this razor is capable of producing a near manual razor shave for only 50 bucks at the time of this review.<br /><br />I can run my hands over my face against the grain, and feel no stubble when used dry. It does struggle in some tight spots and needs more passes in them. My Wife took what we named the face on face test. She was very impressed.<br /><br />The charging dock works well. The plug for the wall outlet is bulky. It comes with some oil, a plastic cover, and a small brush too. No travel case or cleaning agents in case you were wondering.<br /><br />Using lotion seems to feel better, but the dry shave didn't irritate my 37 year old skin, so no need for me. The trimmer works well too. This has to be the best trimmer under $50 by far, and it beats many from 50-100 that I've tried.<br /><br />It's nice looking and solidly built. Replacement heads are 20 bucks, or even less if you buy a 3 pack. That's just another added benefit as rotary usually runs 10 more.<br /><br />Cleaning is easy. Just take the top off and almost all the hair comes out. Use the brush for what's left. Wet shave cleanup seems best with vinegar or alcohol.<br /><br />I'll have my Wife try it out and report back since I saw some female reviewers to confirm how well it works for them.
  668. Bought this for my husband and he really likes it. He's had Braun shaver's before. They last about 3 years with a change of heads.
  669. I have owned three shavers, first a Norelco, then a Remington and most recently a Philips. The Philips was by far the best of the three brands and gave my light beard a decent shave (I have difficulty growing a full beard, with gaps in it in my cheeks where hair refuses to grow.) Since it was time to replace the shaving screen and cutters, I went shopping for a new one.<br /><br />Enter the Braun 340-S-4. I was attracted by a favorable customer review on Amazon by someone with a similary light beard growth, and also by the price ($59.95), so I gave it a try. I didn't opt for the pricier 380-S which seems identical except for a carry case and a setting to retract two of the 3 cutter screens for shaving under the nose (my 340-S works fine under my nose with all 3 screens.) The shaver arrived, was easily charged, and I have used it for almost thirty days now. It finally glowed red on turnoff about five days ago to indicate the battery was getting low and I recharged it overnight.<br /><br />IMPRESSIONS: It shaved my face comfortably and remarkably close, closer than my Philips when it was new. It is quieter than any electric shaver I have used, cleans up easily under streaming water, and I air dry it overnight with the shaver screen head assembly removed. Otherwise it doesn't seem to dry completely before next use, and I was used to doing this with my old Philips.) The shaver has a clip-on plastic screen guard which also covers the power button for safe traveling (so much for needing an unnecessary plastic carry case with the 380-S) and I keep the guard on the shaver when it isn't being used. There is a nice, lightly-weighted stand to keep the shaver upright on your counter when not being used and it has rubber tips on the bottom to keep it gripping the counter firmly. The stand also has a connector to connect the charger cord so it will automatically charge when on the stand (I don't have a nearby outlet on my bathroom counter so I charge it in the living room when necessary.) The trimmer slides up into position with a push of the thumb and works well.<br /><br />What else can I say? Braun has made a wonderful, capable, quiet and convenient electric shaver that shaves my beard type comfortably and close. It's priced well and I'm impressed. I haven't tried to wet shave with it and see no reason to start.

  687. My Norelco of, oh, let's say 14 years because who can tell, finally started to go on me and I decided it was time to upgrade, after enveloping myself in the bevy of reviews and opinions in this apparently gargantuan electric shaving community it became clear a foil shaver would resolve my irritation issues - or so I was told. Well I'm happy to report in a time when we are constantly lied to this was not the case, the shave is much faster, very close, precise, and the attached trimmer is miles better than the rarely-used apparatus on my old one. I've even taken to using it for back hair and keeping the sideburns in check, it's so good the first time I cut off more than I thought it could handle yet the trimmer sliced through the sideburn like a hot knife through butter. The sole reason I dock a star is the planned obsolescence, which is something I will always hold against a product, the reason Norelco lasted through three and a half presidential terms is the ability to use it while plugged in, thus bypassing the dead battery, Braun has chosen to gloss over this feature. I am left wondering if I can rip it apart to replace the battery, google indicates I can take it apart, but indeed it seems replacing the battery is another matter entirely and I expect Braun would devour two legs and five fingers to do so.<br /><br />Overall I am very satisfied with the closeness of shave, the lack of irritation, and the features of this shaver, and dissatisfied with planned obsolescence.
  688. My shaver [[ASIN:B0021AG0Z6 Panasonic ES8249S Nanotech 4-Blade (Arc 4) Electric Shaver with Vortex Cleaning System]] that I've been using for the last 2 years won't charge properly and since it was still under the warranty (22nd month) I sent it to Panasonic for replacement. I didn't know how long it will take for me to get the replacement so I started using the disposable manual razor blades such as Gillette Fusion/Mach 3 etc. My skin probably was used to electric shavers by now and couldn't handle the manual blades and I had so many cuts, burns and bumps from those. Plus these are expensive and a rip-off. Long story short I wanted some cheap electric shaver which would serve me for a few weeks and I thought I will try a different brand other than Panasonic to see how it compares with my original razor.<br /><br />The main criteria were -<br />1) Wet & dry shave - I have thick facial hair and shave daily and I prefer the wet shave, even if its just rinsing with water<br />2) Foil shaver (eliminates all Norelco products) - read everywhere that foil shavers give closer shave than rotary so I'm sticking with foil for now<br />3) 120-240 V for travel purposes<br />4) Under $50.<br /><br />There were only a few shavers that met this criteria, among those under $50 were Braun 340S-4 and Remington F5-5800A. Braun was $48 + tax after a $10 coupon and Remington was $44 + tax. I decided to go with Braun.<br /><br />So far I'm super impressed with the shaver. When you switch it on the first thing you notice is that how silent this is compared to the Panasonic. The shave is so close and soft without any cuts, rashes or skin allergy. I feel the closeness of the shave is better than Panasonic has ever been, even when it was new, and Panasonic is rated very high here on Amazon. This shaver is essentially the same as 380S-4 (which has an additional switch for closer shaves under nose, neck etc., comes with a pleather pouch and has 3 indicators for battery charge vs. two on 340S-4). Panasonic was never good near the neck area and this Braun does so much better than Panasonic. Probably because Braun has a narrower head (3 blades) vs. the wider head of Panasonic (4 blades). Perfect scenario were less is more! It takes about 5-6 minutes for a very close shave, which also I think is lesser than what Panasonic used to take.<br /><br />There is a trimmer which can be used for sideburns or moustaches but I don't like the design and location of where it is (its on the back with a sliding mechanism) and I usually use a disposable razor for that. It also comes with a small stand where you can attach the power cord and I use it as the charger/stand. This is a major convenience for me since I was used to just putting the Panasonic back in to the cleaner/charger. The cleaners are mostly a waste and running the shaver in water with liquid soap is more than enough. There is also a plastic head cover which protects the head while traveling, but I wish it case with a case.<br /><br />I've only had it for two weeks so I can't comment on the durability.<br /><br />Cons -<br /><br />Build quality is not the same as Panasonic (well its cheaper). The power switch feels flimsy and I have a feeling it won't last very long. Especially if you do wet shave and clean your shaver every few strokes in running water.<br /><br />Overall 5 stars. Just for that super close, soft and smooth shave! Also in the long run these are cheaper than Gillette blade refills.<br /><br />-- Update May/2014 --<br /><br />Panasonic sent me the replacement for ES8249S under warranty. They actually sent me the latest one [[ASIN:B005DKKBP6 Panasonic ES-LV81-K Arc5 Men?s Electric Shaver Wet/Dry with Multi-Flex Pivoting Head and Automatic Cleaning System]]. Haven't used it yet, but kudos to Panasonic for standing behind their product and warranty policy. I'm still using Braun now because the shave is so smooth and close.
  689. This razor is extremely comfortable. I have shaved with 5 blade manual razors and rotary shavers, but I always end up with red bumps on my neck. I play violin, so I would get ingrown hairs and a burning pain that lasted all day, no matter how often or gently I shaved. With this Braun, my neck only gets a little red, and any irritation is gone within half an hour. My only problem with this is that I have trouble getting a close shave on my neck and along my jawline, because the hair grows in all different directions. Perhaps I just need to adjust my technique. Either way, the comfort is worth it in my book.
  690. Compared to the Braun 190s-1 which I have been using for the past 7 years, this shaver is quieter, more comfortable and smoother on the skin and provides a closer shave. Unlike some other Braun shavers, this one does not have a swivel head, which is fine. The instructions state that it should be charged for 4 hours the first time and subsequent charges take 1 hour (after it is completely discharged). It has a plastic case that covers the shaving head and start button.
  691. The razor does what it is supposed to in a satisfactory fashion. Overall squarely mediocre in operation, it'll give a nice shave eventually it just takes more patience and passes than the electric razor i had years ago, which to be fair, was a rotary style and more expensive.<br /><br />I still like and intend to use this razor until the head needs replacing so it isn't horrible. In my experience it works best in this order by application; wet shaver &#60; dry shaver &#60; just out of the shower and patted dry/warm dry towel. In the shower it ran downright poorly so if that is your intention i would look at other options.<br /><br />My reason for purchasing was equal parts a preference for electric and frugality. With a standard razor (mach3) i used to go through a blade every 4-5 days @ ~$2 a blade that is $150+ a year. So this razor will pay for itself in a couple months and the same could be done with a top of the line model with a few more months. Used daily or near daily it doesn't take -much- longer to get a good result, but it does sap away a minute or two extra each morning. After a long weekend i would recommend a standard razor around if time is short.<br /><br />It doesn't hurt, pull hairs or anything like that, just misses a few every pass especially on my neck and corner of my jawbone. Looks and feels nice, battery seems good. Considering the price i basically flipped a coin between a 3-4 star rating, it really is a good value, just not great one for my face. Every face is different after all.

Just a warning: do not skip a day, and if you ever skip two, best keep some good old fashioned cheap bic's on hand. Maybe it's impossible for an electric shaver to shave this close and have the ability to cut a couple day's stubble. I don't know. But since owning this one I have, out of necessity, become much more consistent in my daily routine.

  708. This is my second Braun electric shaver. After about 5 years, the old one had a battery that would not charge well, so I opted for a new one.   709. I can say that this shaver is the best one I've ever owned and that's something coming from a guy who is 53yo. Mainly owned Panasonic before and they tend to go blunt quickly. This new Braun seemed to catch the stubble much better over all contours, getting close under the nose and clearing away longer hairs. Had a very good feel to it, let alone my smooth as a baby face. Results are as close as a disposable shaver blade. Single charge lasts longer than any other cordless shaver I have owned. The charger plug is small and the base unit is small. The cord is stretchy curled so you don't end up with a long wire all over the place. 6 months ago I bought the single foil Braun Traveller battery shaver and was very impressed with it. It also shaved very close. However, after constant use over 6 moths, it is not shaving as close as it once did. I'm hoping this new 3Series will keep doing its excellent job for many more months.

  790. it is ok, not that clean.
  791. This razor works fine. My only disappointment is that it does not work while plugged in. I assume this is a &#34;safety&#34; feature, since this razor is designed for wet and dry operation, to keep Braun from getting sued by someone who tries to plug it in and use it in the tub or shower.<br /><br />My previous razor was a Braun Series 3 that looks almost identical, except it is gray in color instead of blue. That one worked either on battery or while plugged in, but was not advertised as waterproof.<br /><br />This is a small complaint, I know, since the battery will get me through a week or so before I need to recharge it. I would just prefer to have the option of using it while plugged in- don't want to get caught with a dead battery when it approaches the end of its useful life, and not be able to shave until it has sat on the charger.<br /><br />On the plus side, however, the waterproof feature is nice for cleaning. I can empty the compartment of whiskers after a shave and run it under the faucet for a few seconds, and it is as clean as when I took it out of the box. For me, this is much less hassle and more efficient than the models that come with a stand for charging and cleaning. Those cost 2-3 times as much, and you still have to deal with frequently changing the cleaning solution- which evaporates quickly and is also expensive. I even tried mixing my own (rubbing alcohol with a bit of aftershave), which works well and is less expensive, but is still more of a hassle than it's worth to me. It is far simpler to just run this razor under the faucet briefly after a shave.
  792. When it's not tugging on hairs, it's missing them entirely.   820. I have been a Braun shaver user for over 20 years. The one I bought in 2005 was still going strong but my charger cable got damaged and I could not find a replacement. I decided on impulse to just order a new shaver. I had been curious about wet/dry shavers and I saw that this one was around $50. I took a chance on it.<br /><br />This shaver does a surprisingly good job. I use it in the shower just after washing my face. It works just about as well as any electric shaver I have used. I still use a blade razor to shave my neck. I use the Braun to get the cheeks and chin area that are very sensitive.<br /><br />I like the design of the shaver a lot. It fits great in your hand and has a great grip to it. I like the charger cord that coils like a phone receiver cord. It is so much easier to handle than a long straight cord.

  822. This redesigned Chinese-made Braun gives me the best shave I have had in several years. It's my THIRD Braun shaver, all in the 300-series. Avoid the gimmicky wet/dry system shavers. They are a waste of money and the refills will bankrupt you!<br /><br />This particular model is a barebones middle-of-the-pack offering but it does a GREAT job and it's priced very right. Although it's all plastic drive mechanism may not last as long as the previous Braun designs, who wants a 5-year-old plus shaver anyway? For those who claim they cannot get a close enough shave with this model, I ask &#34;What kind of Brillo pads do you have stuck to your face?&#34;<br /><br />The shaver head floats and has a nice springy feel as it glides over your face and provides a smooth and close shave. It takes a few passes but the results are outstanding. The sideburn/mustache trimmer is also extremely effective. It provides for a nice, clean cut line - a big improvement over older models. I like the feel of the ergonomics and shave angle that the grip provides along with the lightweight travel recharger that comes with it.<br /><br />The only part that sucks is the cheap, sloppily fitting, doesn't-stay-attached protective plastic cover. Geez, Braun, include a cheap carrying case already! Otherwise, a winner on all counts! Get one!

  899. Some things never change! Perelli makes the best tires, Sony makes the best TVs, Leica makes the best cameras. And Braun makes the best shavers, offering the best construction and design, sharpest blades, the strongest motors, the greatest longevity, and the closest shave in the business!<br />Specifics, you want? Okay!<br />The first thing you notice upon opening the 'tamper proof' packaging is the robust construction and materials used for this shaver. It feels 'solid', like it could easily survive several drops to a tile bathroom fall without so much as a scratch. If you're REALLY observant, you'll see why. While constructed largely of plastic and other synthetics, they're the same industrial grade materials used in your Nikon and Canon DSLR bodies and lens housings. Even the molded handle is the same tough, 'grippy' rubberlike compound as the handgrips of your Nikon D7100, and exhibited similarly excellent ergonomics. While I haven't subjected the shaver to any MIL-STD-810J shock tests...nor do I plan to...these are TOUGH materials, designed to last! My 'old' Braun shaver 'resigned' after 15 years of loyal, unwavering service. How's that for 'product longevity'! The entire shaver housing, including the encapsulated power switch, side trimmer, and motor to cutter head coupling are fully sealed and waterproof. This shaver is intended for both wet and dry shaving. I've tried it in both dry and in the shower (using only Ivory handsoap for 'shaving creme') and performance is exemplary however you prefer to shave; \\"baby's butt smooth\\"...every time! All the more impressive given that my Nixon-esque beard is more like high-carbon steel wire, case hardened to Rockwell C-70, than actual human hair. The powerful motor in this instrument cut through my facial flora more like a laser than a razor. By contrast, Panasonic and Remington best just 'couldn't cut it', their motors sounding anemic; as if they might \\"stall under load\\" at any moment, and worse, after 15 minutesuse, they still left me in need of a shave! The Braun, as I said, left my face perfectly clean and smooth, without ANY burning or irritation.<br />In conclusion, I am delighted to confer upon the Braun Series 3, 340S-4 shaver my very highest recommendation. In my opinion, and the opinions of MANY other lifelong customers, Braun shavers have always been the very best you can buy, and it looks like they always shall be!
  900. My previous shaver is also a Braun from the 5 series. I have been using it for over ten years. Of cause with the time , as any battery, the charging will be more often. The cut is perfect for an electric shave.<br /><br /> I was disappointed with the lack of a travel case. I didn't pay attention when I ordered it, considering that as a given. All my previous shavers, Philips, Remington, Norelco and Braun came with a travel case, some sophisticated, some simple but it was part of the package. Cutting corners to increase a little bit of the profit gives a black eye for the Braun brand..

  930. Did not see any ratings in CR for most of the shavers on the market. Have owned well reviewed Panasonics for my last two razors. They have been fine, but I didn't really like the \\"vertical\\" orientation of the trimmer, In addition, although I have gotten a fairly close shave it takes several passes. and the replacement screen/blade combo is fairly pricey. I purchased this razor for about $20 more than the screen/blade combo for the Panasonic and overall prefer it to my more deluxe Panasonic. The Good - It provides as a close shave with less passes in comparison to my Panasonic - I like the trimmer better - I like the stand - It appears to be marginally quieter than the Panasonic (possibly because it is operating at lower speed) - Replacement parts are slightly less expensive - Still can shave wet if you desire and easy to clean with water (although it \\"shakes\\" out better than my Panasonic so I don't need to clean it as frequently) The only feature you give up (that I value) is the much more precise indication of amount of charge remaining (however you can easily finish your shave when the light comes on and it recharges in about an hour)

  936. I'm in my mid-50s, and I've been shaving for a good forty years. I've shaved with the single blade &#34;safety&#34; razor, the Sears brand of Norelco, the real Norelco, Remington, twin blades, triple blades--you name the blade and brand, I've probably tried it. Include in that list a variety of shave creams, soaps powders, and methods. Each one left my face bleeding and feeling raw; the LAST thing I wanted anyone to do was touch it. Television ads left me confused over how any guy could stand to have a woman run her hands across his face after a shave. (Of course, I know they're models and it's advertising, but still...) I have always had a very heavy beard. Shaving every morning is a necessary evil, and if there's an important evening event, I have to shave twice a day. (My skin usually needs a couple of days to recover from that.)<br />I bought the Braun Series 3, hoping that a wet shave electric shaver might be the answer. Is it ever!! I still shave every day, but the closeness of this Braun shaver allows me to shave at 5:00 am and still look good for an evening engagement. My face probably hasn't felt this consistently smooth since I was eleven years old. I know this, because I can finally actually touch my own face without it feeling irritated, and definitely without any stubble...at all.<br />If you have a very heavy beard, sensitive skin, and are tired of frequent cuts, razor burn, and just plain shaving irritation, this shaver is absolutely the answer. You won't regret this purchase.

  940. A Note Upfront - THE RECOMMENDED REPLACEMENT FOIL AND CUTTER IN THE AMAZON AD IS THE WRONG ONE. You need a 32b, not a 30b (No, that's not a bra size).<br /><br />I've owned Norelco, Remington, and Braun, and the Braun is the best. This is my third Braun series 3. The Braun shaves closer and with less irritation than either of the other two. Also, the Remington eats it's foils with disturbing regularity--I was routinely replacing them every 3-4 months when the foils ripped. The Braun foil lasts me more than a year and I have a very heavy beard.<br /><br />The only problem I've had with the Braun--and this has happened with both of my previous razors--the trimmer has broken after 4-5 years, requiring me to buy a new razor.

I've had this Braun shaver a month, but wow! What a difference! After scouring reviews, I thought this one had the best reviews for the price, so I tried it.) (There was another one similarly priced, though I don't remember the brand/model. The Braun had the $10 coupon, so I went with that one.) I'm sold. Package says 18mo without a new head--so I hope that happens. Course, the head is only 1 mo old too... (Hmmm.) I don't know how much better those $100 plus models are with the good reviews, but having tried this Braun, I fully expect to buy another one for my travel bag now. The Remington's might have lasted 18mo's...but, I'm now much more inclined to spend a tad more overall to get the great shaving experience.   979. I bought this shaver as a Christmas gift for my husband. He has a course, thick beard and extremely sensitive skin. He's tried other shavers in the past and always ends up hating them. I read many reviews and watched several YouTube reviews on a large range of razors under the $100 mark and this one got the nod. It shaves so much closer than my old Braun I could hardly believe it! Absolutely no skin irritation, no need to shave wet nor use Williams Lectric Shave to get a real close shave. It is much quieter and very ergonomic to hold. Charging is relatively quick and because it's waterproof very easy to clean under hot water. I don't have a really tough beard but I frequently don't shave over the weekend and this razor had no problem cutting through nearly three full days of beard.   985. The beauty of this Braun razor is that you can use it wet or dry - literally. Take it with you in the shower, use it with gel, or use it dry and it works! In fact, if you like a close wet shave you get with a blade, you will be surprised at how close and clean this razor leaves your face when it's wet. The battery charge seems to last forever. With at least once-a-day use, sometimes more, the charge lasts a month or more. Extremely easy to keep clean - pop the combined grill and blade top off, rinse it and the main portion of the razor under water, and done. Trimmer is the right size and shape for easy beard/mustache care. Full beard wearers will probably want to get a dedicated beard trimmer for uniform length overall, however.
  986. Best Braun I have ever had. Smooth, quick and comfortable and a great price. Fit great in the hand and looks cool
  987. I purchased one of these Braun Series 3 340S-4 shavers at Best Buy to replace my older Braun 8985 shaver. My cleaning station was broken and the 8985 could not be cleaned under running water, so it was a pain every day to keep it clean. I figured getting a newer model that was water proof would be a great idea, boy was I wrong.<br /><br />I've used the 340S-4 for about two weeks now and it's been an awful experience. Every shave wrecks my skin, and no matter how long I shave for there are STILL stray hairs all over. When used wet, with shaving gel or shaving cream, it is utterly mediocre and takes twice as long as my old razor to finish shaving my face. When used dry it's about as good as sandpaper and sharp rocks and there is never a point where I say &#34;Yes, my face is now nice and clean shaven.&#34;. The reason it has so much trouble shaving necks, as many other reviewers have noted, seems to be a core engineering problem. The shaving foils that do the cutting are spaced too far away from each other and have too much plastic bezel surrounding them, which means on any curved surface it has a great deal of trouble making contact with both at the same time. You might as well be shaving with a $20 single foil razor, which coincidentally is about the quality of shave you're getting from the 340S-4.<br /><br />It gets 1 star for being water proof and for being easy to clean under the sink. If I could have given it zero stars I would have. What a waste.
  988. Purchased this razor to replace an older Braun I have had for years. I looked at several different brands and models and thouught this one looked best for my needs. Major positives are<br />Great battery life. I have a relatively light beard so I can shave for maybe 2 - 3 weeks prior to recharging. This is similar to my previous Braun which also had an excellent battery.<br />Good shave. Not as good as a razor - no electric razor is - but good enough for me.<br />Razor is light to hold and relatively quiet.<br />I like the red light that comes on to let you know the battery needs to be recharged.   990. I've had this product for about 4 months, purchased it on Amazon. I wanted to use the device for awhile before writing a review.<br /><br />First, let me start by saying I was never a big fan of electric shavers; I preferred using a regular razor with gel or foam. The reasons that led me to making the switch were two-fold:<br /><br />1) razor cartridges are getting so ridiculously expense to the point of absurdity, and they don't last nearly as long as the manufacturers claim, especially at the prices they're charging.<br /><br />2) I have issues with sensitive skin, razor bumps/irritation, and ingrown hairs on the neck. I needed something easier on the skin.<br /><br />My first requirement was that the electric razor be 'wet-shave' capable. The second was a reasonable price. This entry level Braun model seemed to fit the bill on both counts and got good reviews here on Amazon.<br /><br />I've dry shaved with it a couple times when I was in a rush, and it does a decent job in dry mode. But I prefer to shave wet. I find that the shaver works nicely paired with Neutrogena's Skin Clearing Shave cream (an actual cream, not gel or foam) on a slightly damp face.<br /><br />At first I was unimpressed, but rather than blame the device right away, I experimented a little bit and found that I was going too fast on the strokes. To get a good shave with this device, you need to be slow and deliberate.<br /><br />Like all electrics, it struggles with closeness a little bit on the neck area, but that's to be expected. When used with a cream and on a damp face, it gets most hairs, and most importantly it irritates the skin a lot less. Sometimes if it misses a few I'll make a quick pass with a disposable to get any remaining hairs.<br /><br />Overall, I'm pleased with the product and think the build quality is great for the price. It could be a little better, but given that this is an entry level device and not one of Braun's top end models, it does an admirable job.
