  1011. UPDATE 9/3/2014: The razor is still working fine ,however, I have begun to wish for a cleaning device for it, its incredibly hard to clean the \\"combi\\" blade well to get all the hair removed, it still works fine, its just a matter of sanitation. Also I've realized this works best if you use it every day contrary to the manuals recommendation of waiting 2-3 days between shaves, it takes longer to get rid of all the hair in that 2-3 day situation requiring multiple passes. However every day cutting my face stays smooth of almost all stubble. I also noticed after 3 days of not using it while I was away on a trip that the charging contacts had a green \\"rust\\" or oxidation on them. I'm not sure where that came from because I do my best to dry the shaver out, it still charges and runs fine, but that's something I have to look into further down the road. I still think it's good but could probably use a bit more power to the motor.<br /><br />The reason I originally bought this was because so far my entire life I've used disposable razors (my entire life shaving has only been like 5-6 years lol), and for some reason kept cutting my face. I thought of this as a great alternative, I had also heard of Brauns superior build quality. I had grown some serious stubble (+4 days) and put it to the test. It takes quite a bit longer than a normal razor, but the outcome is better, at least for me I got no irritation, and no bumps because I used it with a cooling shaving cream. Also with this, unlike normal razors you go against the grain, and if you have any tight corners in your face it will miss those and you have to pass them again, hence why it probably takes slightly longer when you first use it. However it could be a time saver, if you use it in the shower. It feels very nice in the hand, it's very lightweight, and I feel it could last much more than 2-3 years. It also comes with a cleaning brush and machine oil for it. A slight recommendation would be up the motors power a bit, I feel it wouldn't have missed stubble if it had a bit more power too it.<br /><br />Shipping: The shipping for this in the Philadelphia area SUCKED!! Google A-1 international courier service amazon and you'll see all the bad reviews, it was guaranteed for me at 8:00 pm that night, and got it close to midnight when a suspicious unmarked car parked in front of my mailbox and shove the box in the mailbox as tight as possible, and proceeded to call me from an unknown number saying my amazon package had been delivered.   1013. in short, bad at wet condition; ok in dry condition.<br /><br />First of all, I stopped to use electrical shaver 12 years ago since I hate the painful feel after shave. I did try to pull my face a little to solve this issue, but it didn't help. It just leaping when I push/pull forward (always 90 degrees blade to skin surface). I also tried with all angels (blade to skin), nothing really helps.<br /><br />In consider I already forgot how good/bad electronic shaver was, I think 3 stars is fair for this one.   1017. Before buying any electric razor do your homework, do you shave everyday? how thick is your beard?<br /><br />I have to shave everyday, my previous electric razor was only a single foil and it felt like it was ripping every hair out of my face! manually shaving would give me a really close shave but later on that day when the hair starts to grow back my skin would feel itchy and irritable and I would end up scratching my neck and then wouldn't be able to shave the next day.<br /><br />This is by far the best electric razor I've ever used, close shave, no pain (cant even feel the hairs being removed) and most importantly no irritation later that day.
  1018. I bought this model to replace my fairly old Braun 7526. I had been buying replacement heads for that one through the years but i thought i might save money in the end by just getting a new shaver instead, also because the battery in my old shaver wouldn't hold a charge for very long any more. Well unfortunately this 340S-4 does not do quite the same job as my 7526. Even with old foil and cutters the 7526 still gives a quicker and smoother result than the 340S-4. It seems to take almost twice as long to get the same smooth result with this shaver than with my old one. I do like the overall operation of this new shaver and the fact that it's quite compact, so i will hold on to it and it will probably become my shaver for traveling. But in the mean time i did order a new set of foil and heads again for my old 7526 which i won't retire for a while.
  1019. My son is loving this, works great for him. Much easier than razor blades and more of a bargin now he is headed to college.

  1023. Performs as expected...its a Braun(duh)
  1024. Bought it for my Dad - he says it's the best! So, we bought one for his nephew.
  1025. Very good product, love it!
  1026. To get a good beard, you will need to have time, because is necessary to pass much time in the same point to get a good job.
  1027. I had never used an electric shaver before. I sent for this Braun from Amazon and received it within a few days. I used it and was pleased. It did a very good job. I will not go back to the old way of shaving.
  1028. works very well the small trimmer could be better
  1029. This Braun 340S-4 is so much better than my previous Braun shaver. The older version (5776) was flimsier. Compared with the older 5776, the construction of the 340S-4 is superior in every way. The Cutter-Foil Cartridge is solidly designed albeit expensive. The 5776's Cartridge was a mess and the trimmer kept disconnecting from the main body of the shaver. I am glad that Braun fixed this in the 340S-4 model.<br /><br />I shave every day, and I shave my full head, not just my face. I find this Braun 340S-4 to be very comfortable, close shaving, well made and non-irritating. I have nothing to say against this shaver, but it IS on the pricy side.<br /><br />I do have to rework some areas of my head and face to get the shave that I want, but I so far have not seen any shaver that did better.<br /><br />I get three shaves from a single charge which is better than the 5776 did, but I miss the fact that the 5776 allowed me to shave while charging, which the newer 340S-4 does not (it will not charge & shave at the same time). Beware, if you sometimes fail to charge your shaver, you may get half a shave. There is a red warning light though, and you probably have a full shave left even when it comes on, but do not ignore it.<br /><br />The engineering of the 340S-4 seems well thought out and built to last, but only time will tell. I got about a year and a half to two years of life from my previous Braun shavers. The feature that spells certain death for the Braun shavers has been the hinge-joint which allows the shaver head to swivel as you perform you shave. It eventually breaks rendering the shaver useless. This doubtful advantage has been thankfully removed in the 340S-4. From past experience, I have noticed that recharge life will gradually shorten over time until the shaver becomes next to useless as well, unless you can recharge while shaving. This is normal for any rechargeable battery, but there is no way to replace this battery in the Braun shavers, so this may be the new Achilles heal of the 340S-4.<br /><br />I do not miss the black carry case of the older shavers because the carry case was poorly designed anyway and would break into two pieces at the flimsy hinge. Also the case would soon warp so that the two halves did not properly align after only a few months of use. This 340S-4 does not have a carry case at all but rather a plastic head cover which is one piece and pretty much gets the job of protection done.
  1030. Now my son can stop using mine! :-)

The best shave is still a disposable multi- bladed razor ranging from a BIC to Gillette. Check the 340s vs the 380s. I can see no reason to spend the extra money for 380s.

  1082. My old Braun's foils lasted 18+ months and the battered shaver still works after 20? years. I am very happy with the Braun 3Series 340S-4 that I bought. Close shave but comfortable. Not loud.
  1083. In the past few years I've owned a Panasonic wet-dry \\"linear motor\\" razor and a Norelco HQ9-head rotary. The Panasonic cut very close, but was somewhat loud and would sometimes miss some neck stubble, leaving scattered whiskers to grow longer and longer. The Norelco was very quiet and got the stubs, but didn't give as close a shave as the Panny.<br /><br />The 340S-4 shaves close, almost as closely as the Panasonic, but is quieter, and it picks up neck stubble well. However, it's still very audible from the next room, unlike the Norelco. So far I've used it for two weeks on its first charge.<br /><br />Unless you need the very quiet operation of a rotary, this razor is a fine choice. The more expensive versions in the Braun \\"S\\" line appear to be built slightly \\"prettier\\" but they have features I've tried before and don't want to pay for again (a \\"cleaning system\\" base). The 340S rinses clean in just a few seconds under the tap.
  1084. Made a nice gift for a senior
  1085. Last month I bought the Old Spice version of this model in red (just because it was a few dollars less when I found it), and to date, it is the best shaver I have used. I am a 58 year-old man. Not all beards and skin types are alike, and mine is of the heavy bristle (now even more stubbornly so, as most of it is gray) growing out of sensitive skin. I shave my head, too. Although these machines are developed for bristle, they work well on hair as well. My last shaver was a spaceship, which I decided to replace when it developed an extra buzzing noise and popped a spring from the cutter/foil assembly. Over-engineered with 5 heads and a several hundred-dollar price tag. It's not rocket science, lads - it's face-shaving, for goodness' sake! The BRAUN 340-s 4 is quieter, smoother, more compact, and cheaper than the competition. You could spend more on a higher model of BRAUN, but I wouldn't. If your wrist doesn't work, you might need a shaver that boasts flexing or sliding heads that 'conform to the contours of your face', or even 'custom' or 'comfort' settings for different beard/skin types. Don't be taken in! This is a man's shaving tool. Why pay more?

  1104. Finally!! It doesn't irritate at all!! It works great. I would say it grabs 98% of the hair, sometimes a few single hairs are left behind and even with running it over them, they still don't get cut, so I just grab the razor, again this is for a few hairs considering all the individual hairs on your face. The back trimmer works great, if you need to get a close trim but not completely smooth. The charge lasts a really long time, I sometimes charge it sometimes don't in between, I have never HAD to charge it because it was dying. Great product, my only regret was waiting so long to get it. I got it when it was 60 or 80 dollars about 6 months ago, can't believe the price dropped so low.

  1126. I have used an electric shaver for more than twenty years. And, over the years, I have acquired several shavers, each of which had its strong points as well as its weaker ones. For example, Hitachi makes shavers with roller blades much like the manual push lawnmowers, and Norelco makes the rotary shavers. The Hitachi is great for one-day growths, but doesn't do all that well with longer hairs. The Norelco (Philips), on the other hand, does a great job with longer hairs, but for me, at least, is not the greatest with a one-day growth. And, finally, my favorite was a Grundig shaver, but the sliding switch just broke, and new ones are no longer available in the U.S.A., just in Europe. So, I am always so grateful to other reviewers on Amazon, because I can often get a good idea from them before ordering.<br /><br />That was the case with this Braun shaver (also because I have had good service from assorted Braun kitchen gadgets). This shaver gets the longer and the shorter facial and neck hairs equally well. The trimmer cuts even longer hairs that crop up low on my neck without irritating the skin. I opted for the model that works in the shower, and I have used it on my wet face just after the shower for a very close shave. The rubber non-slip skin that encloses the shaver is a huge plus. All-in-all, this is as perfect a shaver as I could hope for. I recommend this purchase.<br /><br />Footnote: Be sure to order the Braun 32b Series 3 Combi Replacement Pack. It has the randomly spaced holes, whereas the shaver comes with regularly spaced holes. I expect that when I have to replace the one-piece head with the Braun 32b Series 3 Combi Replacement Pack, I will get as good or better shave.
  1127. I have a medium to light beard and this seems to cut well with a slow-moderate speed, but seems slightly underpowered compared to Panasonics in the same $$ range. Easy to bog-down. Overall, I have been more impressed with the Pannys I have owned, and would buy a Panasonic if I could do it over, as their motors seem higher torque.

  1133. I've been using Norelco rotary shavers since last century, and decided it was time for a change.   1134. After years of buying cheap electric shavers I decided to break down a try a Braun, but thought I'd start with an \\"inexpensive\\" one. After reading many reviews, I settled on a shaver that can be used in the shower and does not have the self-cleaning feature. Many reviews of the shavers with the self cleaning seemed less than satisfactory. And I didn't want to have to buy the pricey cleaning cartridges every few months.<br />I had high expectations for this device and after a month of use it has far exceeded my high expectations. It is built solidly, feels good in the hand even when wet, and gives a shave as close as a blade but without the irritation. The trimmer feature is excellent as well. I successfully hacked an uneven piece of my mustache off expecting it to perform like my previous Remington piece of junk. I only use it for my facial region so I can't comment on how it would work on a shaved noggin or other body parts.<br />There were a couple of reviews expressing dissatisfaction about the battery life. I suspect that those commentators did not read the instructions regarding the initial battery charge/discharge procedure. The instructions are clear and concise (once you get past the obligatory idiot warnings like 'not intended for use in woodworking projects'). Just follow the simple instructions and you should have a long and happy life of shaving. There were other comments about it being noisy. If you consider a slight hum to be noisy, you're spending too much time listening to Barry Manilow music. My Remington sounded like a weed whacker compared to this shaver.<br />I can't imagine that the really expensive shaver models would be any better than this so save your money and just buy this one! I don't typically give anything 5 stars but I honestly can't find a fault with this unit. If I do, I'll adjust my review accordingly at that time.
  1135. Nice razor. Shaves well. Holds charge well. Read some reviews complaining of noise, but it seems quiet enough to me.
  1136. The shaver feels like a quality product and the performance has been great. The product comes with a charging stand but the cord can also be plugged directly into the shaver. This is a huge plus because some shavers force the owner to use a charging stand or station. This shaver is also very easy to clean compared to other similar products. In the end, this is one of the best shavers at this price range. I don't think you can go wrong with it.
  1137. Still using this thing daily. I have had it for 2 years. Nice product

  1158. Even though I had a Braun 8000 series for nearly 10 years, this one compares very closely to the previous shaver, in terms of performance.
  1159. I purchased this model shaver from Wallyworld, but wanted to share my quick down and dirty review here, as Amazon is where I gathered my initial info while standing in the aisle. At the time I didnt have Prime, and I needed it ASAP rather than a few days away. So far, I've owned it 8 months.<br /><br />First off, this is my first real electric. I've had other generic travel foil shavers, but nothing of substantial sturdiness. This is one sturdy unit. It has survived several drops in the shower without any issue. You cant even visually tell its fallen to the floor. Still hums like day one. All well and good. I will say, like most other reviewers, it does take several passes to get a smooth cut, especially on the neck. I've found it easiest to hold the razor so its foils are up and down (perpendicular to the floor), tilt my head back, and make good horizontal swipes like I am trying to slice my own neck. That motion gets the best results with me. It might work with you too.<br /><br />Right, continuing the review...battery life is sweet. I charge it once a week, and shave about 7 minutes a day, 6 days a week...sometimes wet in the shower, or dry before I get in....depending on the previous day's growth. I'd say it does much better dry than wet, but the unit it at home in either environment.<br /><br />The ugly is the head replacement. You read in the manuals to replace the cutting head every 18 months. I must have some radioactive diamond coated whiskers on my face, because my head began to have issues keeping up at month #6. I've dealt with it, and attempted to clean and oil the thing to no avail for the last two months. I broke down and spent the $27 for a new head today, and it went to down like it was day one all over again...which is what prompted me to write this review. Having to spend $27 every six months for a new foil sucks, especially when Braun says it should last 18 months, but the time savings of electric vs manual kind of evens the score.<br /><br />Overall, I am satisfied with the purchase. I am ecstatic about the price compared to comparable brands. I am happy with the build quality. I am happy with the battery life. I am satisfied with the cut (even the annoying areas on my neck that never seem to be cut on the first or fifth swipe). I am neutral on the cutting head's life. I dislike the cost of new heads at roughly $27. The downsides are why I give the 4 star score instead of 5.
  1160. Very poor shaving experience.... Lots of noise for nothing ...

  1163. You don't need to spend 200 bucks on a good electric shaver these days. I was very... surprised at the quality since I had not bought one for years.<br /><br /> This is in the 60 dollar range and is worth every penny a bargain even and it so far (few months) has worked perfectly.<br /><br />I spent 3 plus times as much on my last electric shaver 10 years ago, so it did last.<br /><br />I use them to shave the areas of my face that cut or have rashes over and over... and then lightly shave the rest of my face with the electric shaver. The newer swivel plastic razors in the bags, I use next lightly and the whole thing keeps my face looking clean quickly without cuts.<br /><br />Of course for a moderately close shave, you can use the shaver often but I found that about every 4 days on the neck and so forth, a razor was still needed.But they are always good to quickly run out the door if you are not in your rough look phase.<br /><br />All electric shavers require a quick rinse of the face after to take off the fine dusting of cut hairs... . If you have a raw place that cuts easily and don't like electric shavers generally... I suggest that you consider shaving with this electric shaver first in those spots and don't touch that spot with a razor ever again, then use the good quality plastic razor for the rest.

  1167. I have been shaving with a blade for 50 years. A medical condition required me to make the switch. After considerable research, I picked the 340S. I couldn't be happier. I shave in the shower, with regular soap (Ivory, it suds up well) for lubrication. It shaves 99% as close as a blade. Still a few awkward-angle spots that are hard to get completely, but that was true with a blade too. No cuts, no irritation, same or less time. I've had no problems with it so far (3 months). Every two weeks, I turn it on and toss it on the bed until it runs down fully, then recharge it. It made three weeks once, but I think it might have been slowing down a bit. I am as picky and critical person as you can find (a perfectionist software designer) and I have to say, this product is really well designed and constructed. I was concerned about the few critical reviews here (I checked other sources too -- overwhelmingly positive reviews everywhere, but always a few negative) but my experience has been totally positive. If you get a bad one, send it back for another.

  1170. I always found Braun's shavers to be top notch...a little over designed maybe but typical German. I think this model had some Chinese design! The trimmer on my unit fell off when I opened the package. The problem is that the entire cutter assemble is help by two 1mm plastic studs with the heads melted to act as rivets. This looks like it is done with a soldering iron!!! Poor design, weak, and just so unBraun-like!<br /><br />On the positive side it shaves like Braun, works great in the shower, and the intergrated single piece head cost $20 to replace. My experience in the shower is shavers fall on the hard floor and usually the head breaks somewhere. In this case the cost is 50% of Panasonic and this shaves better. The shave is clean but the grow back seems to have a coarser feel...possibly cutter design.<br /><br />This is first week review. Two stars off for the trimmer design and getting one in perfect packaging that was broken!!!
  1171. Update 2: Six months after buying it, the longhair trimmer fell off. Because it was within warranty, their service center was good about repairing it and sending it back to me within two weeks. Was just a hassle I didn't expect to deal with.<br /><br />Update 1: They have fixed their description on their website and removed the erroneous 'works corded' copy.<br /><br />Original Review:<br />I just received it, and despite what both Braun's website and the product's description on Amazon say, this shaver does not function while corded. The whole reason I went with this shaver is because batteries always die before motors do, which is why you want a shaver you can use while it's plugged into the wall, once that happens. I have not used the shaver yet, but until Braun updates its descriptions to remove this misleadingly nonexistant feature, it earns a one-star.

It takes almost twice as long to shave with the Braun versus the Norelco, because you have to go over the same places multiple times . 3. If I wait three of more days between shaving, the Braun razor sometimes pulls the hairs, rather than cuts. (Yes I do use the supplied lubricant, as well as William Pre-save). 4.   1223. I purchased this shaver at a big box store. I was planning to purchase the same brand shaver I've had for several years, but none were available. I saw the Braun wet/dry at a fairly good price (it came with a few extra items in the &#34;package&#34; deal). Had I not needed it so desperately, I would've ordered from Amazon and waited for delivery. But the old shavers I had were really tearing up my face. The cost of replacement cutters are almost as much as a new shaver! (In the past, I've opted to replace cutters rather than purchase a new shaver. But having replaced cutters several times, it was time to buy a new shaver).<br /><br />Perhaps my skin has changed or maybe the replacement cutters simply are not manufactured at the same high quality as they are on new shavers. Whatever the reason, skin irritation told me it was time to make a change. And even with new blades, my old shaver was uncharacteristically leaving hairs uncut. I'd shave in the morning and not 30 minutes after being in the office, inadvertently brush my face and find a long uncut hair here and there. Even after experiencing this, I was still going to go with the same brand shaver...until I saw the Braun. The wet/dry system appealed to me. I was thinking that shaving gel would add protection for my skin.<br /><br />Well, I was right.<br /><br />I use this shaver with a Gillette shaving gel. Bottom line, the shave is clean, close and comfortable. No more stray hairs left behind. Plus, clean-up is easy. Uncap the foil head, rinse it under hot water, rinse the top of the shaver's main body, re-cap foil head, turn it on to shake out excess water, done!<br /><br />I'm very happy that I purchased this shaver.<br /><br />Update - 12/04/15. Since purchasing on February 21, 2015, the shaver has performed reliably each and every morning. (Initially, I used it as a wet shaver. But, lately, I've used it as a dry shaver. Both ways give me a clean, comfortable shave.) This morning, however, the cutting blade assembly on the pop-up trimmer broke off. All I did was extend it to engage the cutter and it fell off. It appears that the blade assembly is held in place by a sonic weld of two plastic rivets. Once those two rivets give out, the assembly just breaks off. Perhaps a bit of superglue will mend it. But really, I've never had any part on any other electric shaver I've owned (Norelco, Remington, or Panasonic) break. I have to re-rate this shaver from five stars to four stars. It still gives me a great shave, but the pop-up trimmer should not break off in less than a year.mer broke off. All I did was extend it to engage the cutter and it fell off. It appears that the blade assembly is held in place by a sonic weld of two plastic rivets. Once those two rivets give out, the assembly just breaks off. Perhaps a bit of superglue will mend it. But really, I've never had any part on any other electric shaver I've owned (Norelco, Remington, or Panasonic) break. I have to re-rate this shaver from five stars to four stars. It still gives me a great shave, but the pop-up trimmer should not break off in less than a year.

  1240. In 40 years I never had an electric shave and luckily I only have to shave once a week (due slow and blond hair).<br /><br />I got tired of the torture of the blades and decided to try a mid-priced discounted item like this one and I am not sure what to think.<br /><br />It works fine on top, but it just doesn't work very well on my neck. I tried dry, wet, wet and cream and it just &#34;doesn't cut it&#34; (pun intended). I tried every angle possible with so many repetitions that causes more skin-stress than a Gillette triple blade would.<br /><br />Maybe I just have a weird neck hair (it actually grows kind of sideways) because the shave works great on my face, even under my nose.<br /><br />I don't know what to think, but I end up re-touching with a blade after shaving, kind of beating the purpose of having an electric shave...<br /><br />That said: if shaves actually shave your face, then this could be a 5-star item, I give it 2 stars because of the nice finish and design and for working on my face portion of my head:) ..<br /><br />I will give it a couple more tries, maybe a different cream or foam would help.... else I will use it as a pricey trimmer only ...

  1249. I got this as I wanted a shaver for touch ups and daily upkeep. I had tried the ones with the round blades and found them to be lacking. So I figured for the price I would try this one with the foils esp since I read some great reviews on it.<br /><br />First, the best pro is it's price. For a good daily shaver, this is great price. The head comes off easily and can be cleaned with ease. It is also water resistant so it can be used in the shower or with a shaving gel. I found it to give a fairly close shave and not irritate the skin. It comes with a nice charging stand, sample size oil for the blades, a cover for the blades, and a brush for cleaning.<br /><br />I've had some of the expensive self cleaning models in the past and tbh this does all they did for me. The one exception is I have to clean it, which is rather easily done imo. So if you don't mind the extra min spent on upkeep of it, then def go this route and save your money for much more fun things :)

Yeah an actual razor will always have a closer shave, but this shave is ridiculous. For paying $75 for this thing I'd have never expected this poor of a shaving experience....

Great close shave which is nearly as close as a blade. I don't think electric shavers will every be as close as a blade, but this one gets pretty darn close and so far I love it. Comfortable, easy to hold, quiet, and the head blades move up and down if you push on them so it is always comfy against your face.

  1293. Have used this razor several times now. Over the past 20 years I have used every major brand of electric razor. The first brand I tried was Braun. They were great for awhile, but at some point the quality dropped and the price jumped, so I tried other brands with mixed satisfaction.<br /><br />But I have to say, this razor is the best electric razor I have ever used. It is by far the quietest and most comfortable electric razor I have ever used. The comfort may be due to it not cutting as closely as other razors, I'm not sure. I seem to regain my \\"shadow\\" more quickly than I did with the Remington I just retired. Even so, it is so nice to use an electric razor that does not irritate my skin that I don't mind if the shave is slightly less close. I don't dread my next shave now. For what it's worth, I do not put anything on my face before I shave.<br /><br />The only question yet to be answered about this razor is how long will the blade and foil hold up before they need replacement, or how long will the \\"comfort\\" level hold up (which I expect will diminish as the blade and foil wear). For now, I give this razor five stars.<br /><br />Forgot to mention, I'm finding the battery on this razor holds it charge longer than any razor I've owned before. I have been careful to follow the manufacturer's instructions on the initial charge and recharge of the battery.
  1294. This little Braun 3 series is a decent shaver, esp. when you factor in the cost. The fit of the components is very tight & uniform. Not too light, but not to heavy. A slightly smaller shaving footprint might help improve shaving in tight areas (ie: sharp angular jaw lines) but overall does a great job. I feel that my older Braun 8595 shaver is slightly superior in terms of shaving closer. However, that being said the versatility of being able to shave with the Braun 3 dry or wet is a great blessing. Not having to wait after you get out of the shower to shave saves me a boat load of time. While some people prefer to shave before their shower, I prefer after since I use a pre-scrub cleaner to help get a closer, smoother shave with my very coarse hair. Those pre-electric shaving balms do help, but not always (esp. humid weather). Please note, I've only had this unit for a week and have only used it in the shower (w/ shaving gel) twice, but both times the results were surprisingly good. Also, it felt very weird using an electric shaver in the shower. A solid 4 out of 5 stars (due in part to its 'newness' and also the fact that my older 5 year old 8595 shaver did a slightly better job).

  1313. My first Braun razor was a graduation gift in about 1990. That razor was wonderful and has lead to a (so far) lifelong loyalty to Braun razors. However, that first razor with its single foil has never been equaled in subsequent razors (3 or 4). For some reason Braun thinks 2 foils works better. It doesn't work out that way for me.<br /><br />I am giving this razor three stars -- docking two stars each for problems.<br /><br />1. It works ... ok. Not great. Just acceptable. I can live with it and am used to going over an areas several times to get most of the whiskers. This one sill leaves some stubble no matter how many times I go over an area. But it's ok with me for the most part. (-1 star)<br /><br />2. I would dock the razor 1.5 stars for this if I could and considered a 2 star reduction. This razor DOES NOT WORK WHEN IT IS PLUGGED IN. This is very, very inconvenient. It means you have to make sure it is charged in advance when you need to use it. Usually not a problem, but when you forget, it is a very serious flaw that is inexcusable. I assume it is somehow cheaper for Braun to produce it that way, but it is highly aggravating. I would not buy this razor again if I'd known this in advance.<br /><br />If you buy this razor, know this limitation when you buy it.

  1338. I switched to electric razors around 25 years ago because actual razors gave me razor burn and my face was always bleeding after shaving. After a couple of initial electric razors I purchased the Braun 5775 Series razor about 15 years ago and I loved it. I still use it to this day, but it is becoming increasingly hard to find replacement blades, so I thought it was about time for an upgrade. I received the Braun 340-S as a birthday gift from my wife and the razor burn problems have come back in a huge fashion. It takes off all the hair (which is why the two stars instead of one), but it leaves my face a virtual bloody mess with numerous nicks bleeding after every shave (wet or dry shave). Amazon will not take the item back at this point and I don't really have a problem with that. Procter and Gamble does have a money back guarantee (60 Days only) if you are not satisfied with the product. I am currently waiting for any results from P&G. I was really hoping this razor was an upgrade from the older Braun model, being able to use it in the shower and all, but I was really disappointed with the issues of actual razors occurring all over again. I already knew this, but it just goes to show that newer is not always better.

  1355. I had a Braun that lasted many years and when it was time to retire it, I checked out a leading consumer magazine and opted for a Panasonic shaver. Bad move. After a year, I'm back to Braun. I get a better shave, it's quieter and holds a longer charge.
  1356. Other reviewers say this takes too long to shave with. I let my beard grow for two days and timed the shave time. 3 minutes 4 secs. Being of Italian heritage, I would consider my facial hair avg. to heavy in growth an density. Does it shave as close as a blade? No, it doesn't. But it's darn close. I know if I went through the prep and cleanup required to use a blade, it would take a lot longer, and I'm stuck with being at my bathroom sink. I can use this electric anywhere.<br />As for the battery, a blue light is on during use. It flashes when it is getting low. Can't give an exact number of shaves per charge, but would guess 10- 15. When the red light starts flashing, it's time for a recharge. Do not run a lithium ion battery until lit stops functioning. It is bad for the battery. One caveat, this shaver will not work with the ac cord attached. Probably a safety issue, since this shaver can be used in wet conditions, like a shower. Can't imagine anyone using an electrical cord in those conditions, but they do give out Darwin awards. I've had this shaver about 10 months. So far So good.
  1357. Finally found a razor after researching and searching forever and chose this one. Got it for a great deal on amazon. My wife was complaining about my constant scruff and a normal razor was cutting up my face. I had used a rotary shaver before, but wanted to try a foil one instead. It was a good decision except for the when I used it the first time dry, my face broke out with swollen red spots. It was awful. I then started using shaving cream with it and its made a world of difference. I haven't had the red marks since. It doesn't cut my neck hairs like I would like, but I get a great, close shave on my face. This is a great inexpensive razor. The battery life is good, which is still going strong for almost 3 weeks since I opened the box, and the razor works either wet or dry with easy cleaning. I highly recommend it.

  1384. I used the Braun series 3-340s electric shaver one time after receiving it as a Christmas gift. This was the first time I have used an electric shaver in 15 years. I found the shaver gave a very comfortable shave leaving my face smooth and free of any irritation. It ran quietly and was comfortable to hold. Unfortunately the shaver would not start when I tried to use it the second time. The green charging light came on each time it was turned on and blinked continually. It would not run regardless of repeated attempts<br /> and the operating manual comments do not address an issue of this type .<br /><br />I am now pursuing the vendor for a replacement.<br /><br />If the replacement shaves as well as the first one I will feel it is a good purchase.   1385. I had tried electric razors many years ago and always got the same result...a poor shave with way too much irritation. I have been looking for ways to decrease the time spent wet-shaving every day and expected to use this new Braun for touch ups and weekends. Now, I find I prefer using it and only wet-shave for important business or personal occassions. The product is very well-made and well-packaged. It couldn't be easier to use and probably gives me 85-90% of the result of a wet-shave with about 1/3 of the effort. I have not experienced ANY irritation with this razor. It does an OK job when you are in a hurry and can do a great job if you take your time (3-5 minutes). The pop-up trimmer is excellent too. I am sorry I didn't get one of these years ago. This razor can also be used with shaving cream in the shower...have not tried this yet but expect it would be great too. The charge seems to last a couple of weeks and fully recharges in an hour. Also, in 18 months, you can replace the cutter for about $20 and essentially have a new razor. Clean up after a shave couldn't be easier: the razor is a snap to clean.<br />Ergonomically, the razor feels sure and steady in the hand and is very attractive and obviously well made. I did a lot of research on Amazon and this razor seemed to have the best price vs. performance ratio of all that I looked at. I don't see how anyone could make a mistake with this purchase unless they have an exceptionally heavy beard to contend with.

  1419. Amazon's suggestion that foil/cutter (Braun 30B) be ordered with this item is incorrect. The Braun website and user manual both specify the cutter/foil cassette 32B (black) or 32S (silver) as the correct part.<br /><br />Get power tools ready to open the package. It is apparently designed to survive a nuclear explosion intact.<br /><br />Now, I wonder if Amazon will refund the price for the incorrect item they suggested.<br /><br />The shaver operates well, I believe most users will be satisfied. It charges quickly, cleans easily, and gives a close shave when used daily. If not used daily, obtaining a close shave takes a bit longer and requires more effort. I have used several shavers over the past decades--this is one of the best.

  1426. I purchased the 340S to replace my Panasonic ES8103S. I was disappointed. First, it feels like you're holding a brick. Second, there is no comparison between the closeness of shaves.   1427. Husband gives two thumbs up.
  1428. I am trying to like this shaver. I received it as a gift after my 7000 series would no longer hold a charge. This one is quieter and lighter than my old one, but doesn't look or feel near as solid (but it is a much cheaper shaver.) I have used the shaver for over 6 months. The first month of shaving gave a really nice shave, but since then it doesn't seem to be as close a shave and feels more abrasive. I would say that the cutter should be replaced every 3 or 4 months. I've been twice painfully bitten by this shaver - the first time when I accidentally switched it off while shaving and it yanked a whisker out, the other time by the narrow joint between the foil and the cutter assembly. The major deficiencies I see with this shaver are: 1) The on/off button is right where your thumb wants to be when holding it, making it very easy to accidentally turn it off while shaving. My older 7000 series had a switch that had to be pressed and then slid upward and so it was practically impossible to turn it off by accident. 2) The plastic cover fits over the cutters and the switch, however it pops off very easily. Rarely will I find it in place even when just sitting in my drawer. The cover won't keep the switch from being pressed. I had this shaver in my luggage during a short trip, only to find that the press of the clothes pressed the switch on even with the cover on it. When I got to my destination, the shaver had clearly been turned on, running down the battery, 3) The cutter assembly has a narrow space between the metal foil and the plastic structure around it. It is very easy for a whisker to be caught in that and the whisker will be yanked out - very painful! In my opinion this shaver is okay for its price, but not near the quality of the older (and more expensive) Braun shavers. For its price, it's good but you have to be willing to accept the poorly placed on/off button and beware that the cutter could painfully snag a whisker. It might be that the new high-end Brauns are as good as my old one was and I might try a new series 7 if I get bit by this one again.

Even after the charge light comes on, you can probably get a couple shaves out of it. You can't use it plugged in, but it will quick charge in a few minutes so you can get at least one shave out of it.   1491. I can end up with a very close shave with this, but it takes a long time. I have to go over and over the same section of skin before it feels smooth. I've even used the trimmer to cut down longer (1/16th) so the main shaver will cut it on the next pass. The shaver also does a poor job of containing the debris. Don't wear a black shirt, or the dust will show on your chest. I've made adjustments to my routine, but I think I'll go back to Norelco when this one's done.

  1496. I researched the under $100 offerings pretty thoroughly and chose this over similar razors from Norelco and Panasonic. All seemed strong but I chose the Braun 3Series because it had the fewest negative reviews mentioning poor quality and also had the lowest cost of ownership (infrequent and inexpensive blade replacement). This is easily the best electric razor I have ever owned, though I will qualify this by admitting that I have only owned 3.<br /><br />It feels solid and is comfortable to use. It gives an incredibly close shave (not quite as close as a blade but pretty close), handles longer hairs that my old razor missed and easily plows through up to 3 days of beard growth without leaving anything behind. I get at least 4 weeks of daily use out of a charge and while it does not have a digital indicator, there are 2-3 shaves still in it when the red light starts blinking so plenty of warning.<br /><br />I have no complaints and would unreservedly recommend this to someone looking for great value in a razor under $100.
  1497. It's really good... the shave is really close to the skin and doesn't hurt.

  1500. Bought this to replace a Norelco triple head that I had for many years. Read all the reviews and felt this model was the best value for the money.   1501. After coming from a very old shaver, this one is a huge improvement, but I can't say it blew me away. It is very durable, holds a good charge and seems to last forever. I'm seriously tempted to get the spinning kind that claim to cover more surface area and offer a closer shave, because I'm frankly disappointed with this. Note, I don't have that much hair growth after a week's worth of time, so it's not like I'm expecting some herculean effort out of this thing. In closing, this is an \\"ok\\" electric shaver, but absolutely nothing to write home about.<br /><br />Pros:<br />Works with wet skin<br />The charger is the same for the base as well as to plug into the device directly<br />Haven't had any battery issues (holds a charge just fine)<br /><br />Cons:<br />Not that powerful<br />Blade on back could be wider<br />Heavily inflated reviews (IMHO).

  1511. This review is specifically for the Braun 3Series 340S-4 Wet & Dry Shaver. I'm a long time Braun fan, and have used the Braun 6820 foil shaver for years. They seem to last 5 years or so before the battery dies - and my last one just did so a month ago. While I was disappointed that I can no longer find the model I'm used to, I researched the available options and decided to try the 340S-4. My original order was mysteriously returned before it even arrived, so I contacted Amazon - kudo's to Amazon customer service who helped me to get another on order immediately and even waived the next-day shipping.<br />The new shaver arrived and I immediately charged it up. I like the charger base, very convenient to stand the razor on and charge when not in use. The razor is light and comfortable to hold, but noticeably bulkier than the old model. This one won't fit in my travel kit, and it did not come with a travel case. It did come with a plastic shield to protect the foil and keep the power button from being depressed in a suitcase. The first thing I noticed when using the razor however is that the dual-foil design has the shorter foils spaced further apart with the long-hair cutter between. The model I formerly used has longer, narrower foils and is easier to maneuver over the face. A dry-shave with this razor is noticeably not as close as my previous razor. It does a somewhat better job when my beard is longer (1.5-2 days growth) than when trying to dry-shave a shorter 5:00 shadow. I don't normally use any electric-shave pre-shaving product, perhaps that would help. This morning I tried it in the shower for the first time as a wet shaver. I quickly discovered that it is useless without some lubricant (I soaped my face with bar soap). Again, it did a passable job, but still not the closeness I am accustomed to. I guess I'll keep it, but my next razor purchase will certainly be less than 5 years from now...
  1512. Shaver was much less able to handle everyday growth than a blade. It was unable to shave soft bristles growing on the neck. More than two day beard growth was painful.   1513. I first used the rotary type of shaver years ago and was never satified with the shave. Then I went to Remington (remembering the days of &#34;if not satisfied, I'll give you your money back&#34;). I think Remington and Norelco are now the same company. I was totally unsatisfied with the Remington, complained, and did not even get a &#34;sorry&#34; letter in response, let alone my money back. I then looked around and went with my first Braun. For my beard and face, it shaved better than any electric I've ever owned. After about eight years and many screen and blade changes, the battery died. I don't need a cleaner and all of the other bells and whistles, jsut a razor that works. So I went with the 340 series. It works better than my old Braun, getting stubble the Remington and Norelco always missed and that my older Braun was beginning to miss. I still need to do an occasional trim with my Quatro 4 and like sometimes to switch to a reguar shave with a Quatro 4 when I want an absolutely close shave. I have to use at least a 4-blade standard razon to get any kind of a clean shave, less than that will not work. But for me, this razor is as close to a blade shave as I can get and, even with the cost of screen replacements, I save a lot of money on Quatro replacement blades.

  1540. I am an electric wet-shaver: I like the ease-of-use, and ability to shave after a morning shower. (I don't shave while showering, and like to use a mirror to make sure I've got all the facial hair.)<br />- I always use hot-water to rinse the shaver during the shave.<br />- big fan of Bigelow shaving cream (green tube), just a pea size amount works.<br /><br />I was a big fan of the Panasonic wet shaver, and I upgraded to the Panasonic ES-8103 last year (after having owned my previous Panasonic for almost 10 years). But it seemed to start shorting-out, and the display started going out, and finally would intermittently be unable to power-on. If you read the reviews of the Panasonic's, you'll see that there (actually) is a fair percentage of failures. Not good, but hard to detect unless you read past the 5-star ratings it does get: read, they've got a lemon problem.<br /><br />So I went with this Braun 340S.<br />* seems to shave just as close.<br />* it's smoother, less noisy, and shaves in less time.<br />* has no problem with the neck (adam's apple) area, without causing cuts.<br />* is less prone to incidental cuts (compared to the Panasonic).<br />* doesn't require the recommended new blades every 6 months, of the Panasonic. (Braun recommends 18 mos.)<br />* cleanup is easier, barely requires anything more than a rinse; where the Panasonic required extensive rinsing.<br /><br />The only place the Panasonic is better, as far as I can tell: it has a better battery, and could almost last 5-6 days on a full charge. The Braun appears it will only last 3-4 days, but I haven't yet run it down to empty (since that is a tough battery cycle to endure, and I would hate to ruin a new shaver).

  1591. I gave up on electric shavers about 5yrs ago. None of them would work. The only one that came close was a norelco, but it tore my face up to much. Went back to straight edge. At 72yrs old my fine skin can't take all nicks and cuts. I bought this Braun as a last ditch effort. I should have done this a long time ago. It's the best shaver I have ever owned.
  1592. At first I thought it was still in the box. Then I thought the cover may still be on. Nope. Then I thought it has a wrapper over the cutting system. Nope. This is without a doubt the worst electric shaver I have ever bought. It is my sixth Braun and I am using my five year old model with five year old cutters and screens.   1593. Husband who has Alzheimers constantly thinks his razor needs replacing (because he forgets to clean it). I go behind him daily to clean, and t works like a dream. It's easier than rotorary blade shavers for him to clean. I'll keep buying replacement parts for this one as he's gone through 3 razors.
  1594. This shaver is better than my previous rotary shaver which cost over twice as much. I can shave in less time too.<br /><br />The shave isn't quite as good a blade but it's very close.<br /><br />The first charge on the battery lasted for 2 1/2 weeks versus 2 weeks the old one. It charged in an hour as advertised.<br /><br />I am very satisfied with it.
  1595. Great product. Fast delivery.
  1596. Great shave for electric razor -- not quite as close as using a standard razor with shaving cream but close.
  1597. Mostly I've ended up disappointed. But ,so far, I'm on my second Braun 340 wet/dry and very happy with it.
  1598. This is the second one that I have bought of this series 3.. First one worked great but plastic rim holding blades broke. Thought I would give it one more try.

  1600. My husband uses it and likes it but he says they all are not as good as they used to be or could be.
  1601. powerful and easy to clean and use I would recomend this shaver for anyone that wants a quick close shave
  1602. Nearly totally ineffective as a razor. Did a terrible job with new growth, several days growth, thick hair, and peach fuzz. Just awful at everything. On top of not being good at shaving, it caused significant irritation and redness (which has never happened with any other razor I've used.)<br /><br />I currently have a cheap three head Norelco razor, and while not anywhere near as good as using a blade, it is at least passable for a quick shave. This Braun is worthless though.
  1603. the shaver provides a close shave on the sideburns and chin area, and a decent but not great shave on ther neck area as well. the shaver runs smoothly and quietly and does not have a large cleaning station. The shaver however does not run on AC power from the war, it must be charged with a cord and then removed from the cord when fully charged in order to work.Shaver does not irritate the neck or chin area and it can be used under the shower or with running water. works best with a wet shave for me. can cut straight, short, or curly hair does not matter. Braun shavers are currently the best foil shavers out there on the market and one of the best overall shaving brands out there. its a must buy if you suffer from skin irritation and have straight, short or long hair!!!
  1604. I have owned countless Panasonic wet/dry shavers over the past 15 years and replaced my last busted Panasonic with this Braun shaver. My review compares this Braun to the Panasonic shavers I've had. I have owned regular Panasonic shavers as well as the ones with the &#34;Linear&#34; motor. I've had the Braun for about 2 months now. I have a pretty thick beard that's still somewhat visible after any type of shave (electric or razor) and I must shave everyday. Regular razors tear up my skin and cause breakouts, so I have to use an electric shaver.<br /><br />Wet shave (while in shower):<br />The Braun is so much quieter than any Panasonic shaver I've owned. The Braun does a nice job with a little bit of foam shaving cream (I don't recommend shaving gels since they are too thick). My shave comes out very close and it only takes about 2-3 minutes. The only part of my face that doesn't come out well is my neck. I usually have to do some touch-ups on my neck after I get out of the shower. I would say the Braun shaves slightly better than Panasonic and a few minutes faster.<br /><br />Dry shave:<br />Dry shaving performance is not acceptable if I was going into work the same day. It simply doesn't shave close enough for my boss' liking. But it's close enough for weekends and days off. Dry shaving is super quick. But I would say the Panasonic shavers work better for dry shaving.<br /><br />Other random thoughts:<br />The Braun seems well made and is a bit bigger than the Panasonic shavers. It charges in an hour using a NiCd battery and I can get about 8-9 days out of a single charge (I expect to charge the unit more often as the battery ages). The trimmer works fine. It also comes with an international voltage charger and a protective cap for the blades to be used when travelling. Braun's marketing material claims this shaver will last 7 years, but I really doubt it! This model of Braun is one of the few Brauns that can be used in the shower- most Brauns are dry shave only. So pay attention to the specs!<br /><br />Overall, I like this shaver better than Panasonic shavers. The problem I have with Panasonic shavers is that the rubber seals break after about 1-1.5 years. When the seals break, water gets in the unit causing the display to malfunction and for the unit to not charge. Panasonic offers a 2 year warranty on most shavers and I sent a couple of shavers in to be serviced, but the seal ALWAYS breaks again a few months later. Then when you get close to the end of the 2 year warranty, the dilemma is &#34;Do I send it in to be serviced again and replace the blades and foil (which are about forty to fifty bucks) and risk it breaking again, or do I buy a new shaver for about ten bucks more?&#34; I always chose to buy a new shaver. (Of course if you use the Panasonic for dry shaving only the seals should be ok for years.) The other problem with Panasonic shavers is the &#34;Linear&#34; motor, which uses a lithium ion battery and is much more powerful than their standard shavers which use NiCd batteries. The Linear motor is so powerful that the vibration loosens up the shaver's case and blade cartridge in a few months and causes the unit to rattle VERY loud when beng used. Interestingly, I found no difference between the shave quality of Panasonic's Linear or standard shavers, but the Linear is a faster shave.<br /><br />Hope this helps.

  1619. I have been using Braun foil shavers for many years. Tried all the other brands... Remington, Norelco, Panasonic, et.al. Used properly, this Braun (& the rest of their models) provides a shave as close as any professional blade can give you. Lately I've been lazy and use it every other day. This gives my skin a good chance to &#34;rest.&#34; On my off day, I just shave my mustache area as well as just above the chin... so I look like a B.U.M. (bum-in-training). If you've never use a high speed foil shaver, you'll want to try different hand grips, angles of attack and mix up your levels of pressure, depending on the specific area you are shaving at that moment. Because of the built in curve of the Braun shaver, you will find that flipping it over will give you different/better results on certain areas, i.e. under chin, mustache, etc. it actually depends on YOUR face and its unique & often subtle features. I'm pretty sure John Merrick used a Braun Electric Foil and look what it did for him.... he was famous! Buy this shaver at this low price, you won't regret it. DC

The unit is well built and lacks the flimsiness I've noticed with a lot of other units<br /><br />That said the shaver does require a little more attention to detail than the rotary style. You have to attack your face from a couple of different angles to make sure you catch the grain of your stubble. This unit also requires a little maintenance with occasional application of machine oil (not a big deal).<br /><br />A blade razor will shave more closely, but this is much less of an undertaking.

  1631. I've been using electric razors for over 50 years and FINALLY, I'VE FOUND ONE THAT REALLY WORKS.   1632. I have been using Mach 3 razors for years. I typically shave every other day and just use bar soap instead of shaving cream. Hey, it works fine! And it only took me a minute or two to shave my face. But then I decided to try a shaver because I was tired of buying mach 3 refills. So I ordered the Braun shaver, mostly because of the name. But when I started shaving with it, I found that it missed a lot of hairs all over my face and neck. I had to go over particular areas on my face and neck over and over again. Compared to the Mach 3, shaving with the Braun took much longer to complete. But nothing changed. Fortunately they have a 60 day money back guarantee so I boxed it all back up and sent it to Braun. It took awhile (about two months), but they finally sent me the refund in the form of a pre-loaded credit card. Thankful that I got a refund, but hate that I have to use an exact total of $76.99.

  1641. Amazing performance! Recommended!
  1642. This razor was a replacement for an aging Braun 5614. This razor is better in a few key ways:<br /><br />1. The 340S comes with a charging stand and a clear plastic cap for the shaver head (thanks, Braun! Long overdue)<br />2. The 340S is much quieter<br />3. The trimmer blades on the 340S are pointed away from the shaver which makes them much easier to use. On the 5614, the trimmer blades and the shaver head both pointed in the same direction. That means that when you used the trimmer, you had to be very careful because the shaver head was just a centimeter or two away from your sideburns, ear, lip, whatever.<br />4. The three cutter heads of the 340S all move independently of each other. This makes the razor very smooth to guide over the face, almost like using a shaving gel. The 5614 used a pivoting head, but all three cutters on the head moved together.<br /><br />The 5614 still gave a great shave, but the 340S is quite an improvement over the earlier models. In my opinion, the 380 is not worth the extra $40 or so because all you get is a cheap storage bag (definitely not worth $40) and the ability to lock the cutter heads. I had that same feature on an earlier Braun model and never used it, so I'm not sure what value it adds.<br /><br />I highly recommend this razor.

  1699. I have used this product for about a month and I like it. I have used a lower priced Braun (100 series) in combination with a Norelco Rotary Razor for years. The Norelco did a much better job with longer whiskers that the Braun, but the Braun could give a closer shave. The new Braun seems to replace the other two. The battery life has been very good so far. I only use the razor dry, so I cannot comment on using it wet. It is a solid feeling razor that seems to be well made. The three heads make shaving around my mouth and nose easier than the older model. I would recommend this product.
  1700. My husband had a 10 year old shaver and traded up to this one and was sorry he didn't do it sooner. He is very happy with this model.
  1701. Holds charge for about 9 days
  1702. I've used Braun 8000 series for years, and they are 3 times the cost of this shaver. The 3-340s is the best one so far. Shaving time under 2 minutes thanks to a really good foil. Minimal indicators and such. It flashes when it needs charging. Who needs all the digital indicators on the more expensive version. Very lightweight and good for travel. Good grip. Trimmer works great on the sideburns. Cleaning is easy, the foil pops off easily and can be gently tapped in the sink. All pros, no cons. For the price, this is an excellent shaver. I highly recommend it. You'll be very pleased with no disappointments. Update 9/23/16. Foil/cutter lasts for about 6 months assuming you shave every day or every other day. If you wait 3-4 days or longer, you're in trouble. Have a Bic razor ready in that case. If you try to use these foil/cutters for more than 6 months you'll spend 10 minutes going all over your face repeatedly, so expect to spend the $26-30 on a new foil/cutter in 6 months.
  1703. Quiet and makes shaving easier. I have had sveral Brauns over the years and they always perform well. I also feel each new one is just improved a little bit more.
  1704. Love it...great shaver for the price. Not as close as a blade, but 85-90% there, and great for not being irritating like a blade.
  1705. I have used an older Braun 4775 for almost 6 years. It never gave me a close shave in my \\"trouble\\" areas of jaw and neck. I assumed the newer models would have improved on this shortfall.   1706. I bought this for my boyfriend for his birthday. He's had trouble in the past with having really bad razor burn. I did a lot of research and found that 1) the Braun brand is best for sensitive skin 2) foil razors are better than rotary for sensitive skin and 3) this is the 2nd best foil razor on Amazon. The price is amazing too. A lot of the other ones were too expensive...like 100+. His skin is so much softer after switching to this (he used to just use the normal cartridge razors). He also used to have red, itchy bumps down his neck but those are mostly gone now. The only thing is that it doesn't get s close a shave as the cartridge razors, but he said that he doesn't mind if it means no razor burn. I would definitely recommend this razor.
  1707. I am very happy with it. I like the ease of cleaning the foil and cutter. Just remove it and hold it under warm water with a little presure and it gets perfectly clean. Getting all the moisture out is another matter. I found that after puting the head back on the body you can vigerously sshake the razor and pound it against the palm of your hand and all of the moisture will come out. Try it. Don Noettl
  1708. Pros:<br /><br />This shaver feels fine, and doesn't cause any irritation which is great. The battery lasts a pretty good amount of time, and the precision trimmer on the back works great.<br /><br />Cons:<br /><br />Does not shave my neck well at all. I can shave my face with this, if I want to have a neck beard left over. I am not sure if it is my hair type or what, but this shaver always leaves hairs behind on my neck. This forces me to go back and touch up with my previous shaver (kind of defeats the purpose of the new one). For this reason I had to knock a few stars off.
  1709. I bought this shaver after a Remington rotary I had for awhile seemed to be wearing out. My main problem with it is that the foil design absolutely will not pick up certain areas on my face without going over repeatedly or going so far as to position hairs with my fingernails. Thicker hair that grows straight out is no contest and this shaver handles it very well, but any thinner/softer hairs that tend to try to grow parallel to my face or quickly curl over just cannot be picked up by this shaver very easily. They won't poke into the holes in the foils on their own, and nothing about the head design makes it easy to encourage these hairs to stand up so they can be cut by the coarse center blade or the foils. My old rotary did not shave as close, but it at least did an 80% job on my face consistently.<br /><br />Short version: if you have thick/stick-straight-out facial hair, this style razor will work great. If you are more of an Eric Foreman/whispy-whisker face in any major area this thing will be a real pain in the butt to use compared to a rotary.
  1710. Very very smooth shave. If you are considering purchasing this shaver get it! Shave lasts full 16 hours.

  1712. In order for this product to work well, you need to be a specific type of man. It became clear after my first use that the product was not designed for men with thicker facial hair nor men with moderately sensitive skin. This product left a very uneven patchy shave, so I thought an easy way to get around this flaw is to simply go over my face several times. By doing this, my face (neck in particular) was more cut up than ever before while using a conventional razor blade. The only reason it earns 2 stars is for design and battery life. If you have a thin pubescent beard with thick skin, this product is for you; otherwise, I recommend looking elsewhere.

  1741. Awesome, holds charge well.
  1742. I've been a loyal Braun user for 30+ years and was always satisfied with their entry-level models. This year, I treated myself to a Braun 720 to see what I've been missing. After using it for 6 months, I bought a Braun 340s and am much happier with that model. Here's why: Shaving: I think Braun optimized the 720 for comfort, but went too far. The shaver head is sprung so soft that it really doesn't do a good job of getting the blades next to your skin to cut your beard. I had to go over and over my face to get a complete shave and was still left with stubble that I could feel no matter how long I shaved or which angle I used. The shaver head in the 340s is sprung much firmer. The result is fewer passes, less time shaving and a noticeably closer and smoother shave. Trimmer: The trimmer on the 720 is just plain terrible. It folds out from the side of the body at an odd angle, sticks out a couple of wobbly inches and has a curved blade (like a letter &#34;D&#34;, with the curve sticking out). What part of a man's face curves inward in a way that will fit that shape? Heads are round, not shaped like an hourglass! The curve means that only the middle half-inch of the trimmer does anything and the weird angle and length mean that it is hard to position to get a clean, straight trim. The trimmer on the 340s, on the other hand, is straight so the whole width can be used and it slides straight up from the side of the body to be close and level with the shaver head, so you know exactly how the trimmer blade is aligned without even looking at it. The result is straight, even sideburns with one pass. Longer hair: I have a short goatee and the 720 shaver head was always snagging my beard (ouch!) when shaving up to the edge of it. I don't have this problem with the 340s. 3 speeds v. 1 speed: The 3 speeds on the 720 didn't have any noticeable effect other than to change the sound of the shaver. The single speed on the 340s works just fine. So, for me, the 340s is the better shaver on performance and ease of use. The cost saving compared to the 7 Series is just icing on the cake.
  1743. fast shipping, but it came wrong name.
  1744. Borderline in producing good shave, also occasionally pulls on some chin hair.
  1745. The razor doesn't shave close enough. Gave to my 16 year old twin boys who I think will be able to use. Kept my remmington that shaves a lot closer.
  1746. I hate to knock off a star here, because this truly is the best shave I've ever gotten from any electric shaver. I have a very thick beard, and more than one electric razor has had to go back because it took too long to shave, or simply couldn't handle the shave at all. This one provides the closest shave I've ever had (electric, that is).<br /><br />But it loses a star because it can't be used &#34;plugged in.&#34; It will shave after a five minute quick charge, but if the battery dies, you can't just plug it in and fire it up. If you plug it in, the power button does nothing until you unplug the charge cord from the razor. Frankly, this would have been a deal breaker for me if it had been clear before I ordered. Once I had the shaver here, it wasn't worth sending it back for an upgrade, because the shave was so good--but I want people to be aware of this!

  1808. Best shaver I've ever owned. I have sensitive skin (get ingrown hairs and bumps with regular razors). I have also &#34;buzzed&#34; my head since I was 19 (I'm now 35). I've tried several different shavers over the years (albeit much cheaper ones) and have always had problems (shave not close enough, irritating, unit breaking, etc). I'm not sure how &#34;close&#34; is considered a close shave, but this one leaves my skin very smooth (feels just as smooth as when I shaved with a razor to me, but without the razor burn or ingrown hairs). The charging station works well; just sits charging next to my sink until I use it. I can also shave a lot faster with this thing. The little &#34;clipper thing&#34; between the foils is pretty cool since it will chop off longer hair before the foils cut down to skin level. I've been using this thing for one month now and wish I had bought something like this when I first started shaving (would have saved me a lot of time and grief over the years).<br /><br />Btw, for those that shave their heads, this thing works great (for me anyway). I get a smooth shave, just like on my face (facial hairs are a lot thicker so I would it expect it to work well on my head). If I'm lazy and let my hair grow out too much (face or head), I run a buzzer over my face/head first before using this shaver.

I expected a close shave when in the shower with shaving cream. I honestly couldn't tell the razor was cutting at all.<br />The charging stand is nice, but a little hard to get the razor to set in the cradle.<br />If you don't hold the razor at the exact right angle it won't cut. And be prepared tp use your free hand to stretch your face to get that really close shave.<br />The produce doesn't suck, but I wish I had spent the money and replaced the heads on my old razor.

  1875. Excellent shaver for not a lot of money.<br />Yes: it takes time to &#34;break in&#34;, but then it gives excellent shaves with no irritation.<br />Yes: it can be used wet or dry and can be rinsed out if needed.<br />Yes: it has a decent sized trimmer<br />Yes: it has decent battery life.<br />I got this to replace an older Remington that had become less than comfortable to use. At first I wondered about the shaver, since I really had to work to get all my beard off. After a couple of days it settled in and now its faster shaving than the Remington. It has two screen-heads and set between them is an older style cutter head for beard hair too long for the screens to handle. It comes with a stand, charger, and battery light. It also has a head replacement light: when it turns on its time to replace the shave head.<br />This is a good razor and it doesn't cost an arm and a leg. My previous shaver lasted me twelve years. I think this one may last longer.
